docs.title: Partner Agent
docs.text:
AI-powered assistant that runs partnership playbooks end-to-end.

The Partner Agent guides you through complex workflows like recruiting a new partner or conducting a QBR, using AI to help fill templates and provide expert recommendations.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Navigate to the agent
cd scripts/partner_agent

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Set your API key
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=sk-ant-...
# or
export OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-...

# Run interactively
python agent.py

docs.title: Playbooks
docs.text:
:material-account-plus: Recruit

Sign a new partner from qualification through agreement.

:material-rocket-launch: Onboard

Activate a signed partner with training and first wins.

:material-calendar-check: QBR

Conduct quarterly business reviews with metrics and planning.

:material-arrow-expand: Expand

Grow an existing partnership with deeper investment.

:material-door-open: Exit

End a partnership gracefully while protecting relationships.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[Select Playbook] --> B[Enter Partner Info]
    B --> C[AI Guides You]
    C --> D[Fill Templates]
    D --> E[Save Progress]
    E --> F[Export Results]
  1. Select a Playbook - Choose the workflow you want to run
  2. Enter Partner Info - Provide the partner name and context
  3. AI Guides You - Answer questions as the agent asks them
  4. Fill Templates - The agent populates templates with your answers
  5. Save Progress - State is saved so you can resume anytime
  6. Export Results - Get filled templates ready to use

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
Run playbooks directly from GitHub with the click of a button.

  1. Go to Actions → Run Partner Agent
  2. Click Run workflow
  3. Select playbook and enter partner name
  4. View results in the workflow summary

Setup Required

Add ANTHROPIC_API_KEY or OPENAI_API_KEY to your repository secrets first.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Customize the Partner Agent to match your company and workflow.

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
The agent reads from config.yaml:

# AI Provider: anthropic or openai
provider: anthropic
model: claude-sonnet-4-20250514

# Template library location
templates_dir: ../../docs

# State storage for partner progress
state_dir: ./state

# Your company context
company:
  name: "Your Company"
  product: "Your Product"
  value_prop: "Your Value Proposition"
  website: "https://yourcompany.com"

# Partner tier definitions
tiers:
  - name: Strategic
    revenue_threshold: 1000000
  - name: Gold
    revenue_threshold: 500000
  - name: Silver
    revenue_threshold: 100000
  - name: Registered
    revenue_threshold: 0

docs.title: AI Provider
docs.text:
Setting Options Default provider anthropic, openai anthropic model Model ID claude-sonnet-4-20250514 AnthropicOpenAI 
provider: anthropic
model: claude-sonnet-4-20250514

Available models: - claude-sonnet-4-20250514 (recommended) - claude-opus-4-20250514 (more capable, slower) - claude-3-5-haiku-20241022 (faster, cheaper)

provider: openai
model: gpt-4-turbo-preview

Available models: - gpt-4-turbo-preview - gpt-4 - gpt-3.5-turbo

docs.title: Company Context
docs.text:
Pre-fill templates with your company information:

company:
  name: "Acme Corp"
  product: "Acme Platform"
  value_prop: "Help businesses automate their workflows"
  website: "https://acme.com"
  industry: "Enterprise Software"

The agent uses this to: - Pre-populate [Your Company] placeholders - Provide context to the AI for better recommendations - Customize prompts and suggestions

docs.title: Partner Tiers
docs.text:
Define your partner program tiers:

tiers:
  - name: Strategic
    revenue_threshold: 1000000
    certification_required: true
    qbr_frequency: monthly
  - name: Gold
    revenue_threshold: 500000
    certification_required: true
    qbr_frequency: quarterly
  - name: Silver
    revenue_threshold: 100000
    certification_required: false
    qbr_frequency: semi-annually
  - name: Registered
    revenue_threshold: 0
    certification_required: false
    qbr_frequency: annually

docs.title: Custom Prompts
docs.text:
Override the default AI prompts:

prompts:
  system: |
    You are a Partnership Expert Agent helping to run playbooks.
    Be concise and actionable. Ask clarifying questions when needed.

    Company context:
    - Name: {company.name}
    - Product: {company.product}

  template_intro: |
    Let's work through the {template_name} together.
    I'll ask you questions and fill in the template.

  step_complete: |
    Great progress! Ready for the next step?

docs.title: Storage
docs.text:
Configure where state is saved:

# Local filesystem (default)
state_dir: ./state

# Templates location
templates_dir: ../../docs

State structure:

state/
└── acme-corp/
    ├── metadata.json
    └── recruit/
        ├── progress.json
        └── filled_templates/

docs.title: Enterprise Partner Program Framework
docs.text: Generic Case Study Based on Best Practices - January 2026

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This framework documents proven patterns for building and scaling an enterprise B2B technology partner program. All specific company names and identifying details have been removed - only the processes, structures, and playbooks remain.

docs.title: Three-Tier Partner Model
docs.text:
Bronze (Registered) - Self-service enablement portal access - Basic sales materials - Deal registration protection - Annual Revenue Target: <$100K

Silver (Certified) - Technical certification requirements - Co-marketing access - Priority lead distribution - Dedicated partner manager - Annual Revenue Target: \(100K-\)500K

Gold (Strategic) - Executive sponsor assignments - Custom enablement tracks - Joint GTM planning - Co-selling motions - Quarterly business reviews - Annual Revenue Target: $500K+

docs.title: 1. Partner Recruitment
docs.text:
Key Activities: - Ideal Partner Profile (IPP) development - Multi-touch outreach sequences - Discovery call framework - Partner pitch deck - Proposal and agreement

Qualification Criteria: - Market presence in target verticals - Technical capability assessment - Cultural alignment evaluation - Revenue commitment

docs.title: 2. Partner Onboarding
docs.text:
Key Activities: - Agreement execution - Certification tracks - Technical enablement - Product training - Deal registration setup

Success Metrics: - Time to first deal - Certification completion rate - Partner satisfaction score

docs.title: 3. Enablement & Growth
docs.text:
Key Activities: - Regular training sessions - Technical support channels - Co-marketing opportunities - Lead sharing programs - Deal support

Growth Levers: - Tier progression path - Expansion into new territories - New product certifications - Joint go-to-market campaigns

docs.title: 4. Quarterly Business Reviews
docs.text:
Agenda Structure: 1. Performance metrics review 2. Competitive landscape analysis 3. GTM strategy alignment 4. Resource allocation 5. Action items

Key Metrics: - ARR contribution - Pipeline generation - Deal registration volume - Certification status - Partner health score

docs.title: 5. Expansion Plays
docs.text: Common Expansion Vectors: - Geographic expansion - Cross-selling additional products - Upselling to larger customers - White-label opportunities - OEM partnerships

docs.title: 6. Exit Management
docs.text:
Exit Triggers: - Performance thresholds - Strategic misalignment - Mutual agreement

Exit Process: - Customer transition plan - Revenue reconciliation - Knowledge transfer - Partnership closure documentation

docs.title: Setup Guide
docs.text: Get the Partner Agent running locally or in GitHub Actions.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.9+
  • API key for Anthropic or OpenAI

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/danieloleary/PartnerOS.git
cd PartnerOS/scripts/partner_agent

docs.title: 2. Install Dependencies
docs.text:
pip install -r requirements.txt

Or install manually:

pip install anthropic pyyaml rich
# or for OpenAI
pip install openai pyyaml rich

docs.title: 3. Set API Key
docs.text:
Anthropic (Recommended)OpenAI 
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=sk-ant-api03-...

export OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-...

docs.title: 4. Run the Agent
docs.text: python agent.py

docs.title: GitHub Actions Setup

Go to your repository → Settings → Secrets and variables → Actions

Add one or both:

Secret Name Value ANTHROPIC_API_KEY Your Anthropic API key OPENAI_API_KEY Your OpenAI API key

docs.title: Partner Analysis Templates
docs.text:
Measure partner program success with analytics and assessments.

Analysis templates help you track partner performance, identify at-risk relationships, and make data-driven decisions.

docs.title: Templates
docs.text:
:material-heart-pulse: Partner Health Scorecard

Quarterly assessment of partner engagement, performance, and growth potential.

docs.title: When to Use
docs.text: Situation Template Quarterly partner review Health Scorecard Identify at-risk partners Health Scorecard Plan engagement activities Health Scorecard

docs.title: Health Scorecard Dimensions
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Partner Health] --> B[Revenue]
    A --> C[Engagement]
    A --> D[Growth]
    A --> E[Sentiment]
Dimension What to Measure Revenue Pipeline, closed-won, growth rate Engagement Meetings, certifications, co-marketing Growth New opportunities, expanding accounts Sentiment NPS, feedback, relationship quality

Pro Tip

Review health scores monthly and reach out to partners showing declining metrics before they become at-risk.

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Partner churn is expensive and almost always predictable. The health scorecard turns subjective "gut feel" into a documented, comparable score so you can act early and allocate PAM attention to the right partners.

Instructions: 1. Score each dimension using the rubric below (0–20 points each) 2. Sum for total score (0–100) 3. Determine health category and recommended actions 4. Score quarterly; track trends over time

docs.title: Partner Health Scorecard
docs.text: Partner: [Partner Name] Tier: [Registered / Silver / Gold / Strategic] PAM: [Name] Scoring Period: [Q# YYYY] Scored by: [Name] Date: [Date]

docs.title: SCORING RUBRIC
docs.text: Score each dimension 0–20 based on the criteria below.

docs.title: DIMENSION 1 — REVENUE PERFORMANCE (0–20 pts)
docs.text:
How is this partner tracking against their revenue commitment?

Score Criteria 20 ≥ 110% of quarterly target 15 90–109% of quarterly target 10 70–89% of quarterly target 5 50–69% of quarterly target 0 < 50% of quarterly target or no revenue

This quarter's revenue: $[amount] Target: $[amount] % to target: [%] Score: ___/20

Notes: [Context — new hire, territory change, big deal slipped, etc.]

docs.title: DIMENSION 2 — PIPELINE ACTIVITY (0–20 pts)
docs.text:
Is this partner actively building pipeline?

Score Criteria 20 [3+] new deals registered this quarter; pipeline ≥ [3×] quarterly target 15 [2] new deals registered; pipeline ≥ [2×] target 10 [1] new deal registered; pipeline ≥ [1×] target 5 No new deals but existing pipeline > $0 0 No active pipeline

Deals registered this quarter: [#] Open pipeline value: $[amount] Pipeline / target ratio: [X×] Score: ___/20

docs.title: DIMENSION 3 — ENGAGEMENT (0–20 pts)
docs.text:
Is this partner responsive, present, and invested in the relationship?

Score Criteria 20 Weekly syncs attended; responded to all comms within [2] days; attended [1+] company events 15 Bi-weekly syncs; responsive within [5] days; some event attendance 10 Monthly check-ins only; occasional non-response; minimal event participation 5 Sporadic contact; often unresponsive; no event attendance 0 Effectively dark — no meaningful contact in [60+] days

Sync cadence: [Weekly / Bi-weekly / Monthly / Ad hoc] Avg response time: [days] Events attended this quarter: [#] Score: ___/20

docs.title: DIMENSION 4 — CERTIFICATION & ENABLEMENT (0–20 pts)
docs.text:
Is the partner investing in product knowledge?

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this roadmap to define, sequence, and communicate all critical enablement milestones for partner development.

Steps: 1. Review each phase and milestone. 2. Assign owners and timelines for each activity. 3. Track progress in a shared system with your partner. 4. Reference the "Related Templates" for supporting information. 5. Review and update at regular check-ins and QBRs.

docs.title: Partner Enablement Roadmap (Strategic & Phased)
docs.text:
Purpose: To define, sequence, and communicate all critical training, certification, content access, and go-to-market enablement milestones required to transform a new or developing partner into a highly competent and productive member of our ecosystem. This roadmap provides clarity and a shared vision for partner development.

Core Sections & Example Prompts (Expanded with Strategic Context):

docs.title: I. Foundational Onboarding & Program Immersion (First 30 Days) (Corresponds with Partner Onboarding Checklist II.3)
docs.text:
• Day 0-7: Welcome & Access ("Signed, Sealed, Delivered")
  • Action: Official partnership agreement signed.
  • Action: Welcome email from executive sponsor & dedicated Partner Manager (PAM) sent.
  • Action: Access to Partner Portal, PRM, and essential tools provisioned and validated.
  • Milestone: Partner confirms access and completes profile in Partner Portal.
  • Week 1-2: Program & Product Fundamentals ("Understanding the Landscape")
  • Action: Attend live or on-demand Partner Program Overview webinar (covering program structure, benefits, rules of engagement, key contacts). (Refer to: Partner Program Architecture I.6)
  • Action: Review core product overview materials (solution briefs, introductory videos, target market).
  • Action: Initial 1:1 call with PAM to discuss 30-60-90 day goals and enablement path.
  • Milestone: Partner can articulate the core value proposition of [Your Company] and the basic structure of the partner program.
  • Week 3-4: Initial Sales & Technical Orientation ("Learning the Ropes")
  • Action: Complete "Sales 101" online training module (covering basic pitch, ICP, key differentiators). (Refer to: Partner Training Deck III.2 for content)
  • Action: Complete "Technical 101" online training module (covering basic architecture, key features, integration points). (Refer to: Partner Training Deck III.2 for content)
  • Action: Access and explore the sandbox/demo environment.
  • Milestone: Key sales and technical contacts identified within the partner organization.

docs.title: II. Role-Based Learning Paths & Certification (Month 1-3)
docs.text:
• Learning Paths (Defined by Partner Role - Sales, Pre-Sales/Technical, Marketing, Delivery):
  • Sales Path (Month 1-2):
    • Training: In-depth product training, competitive positioning, objection handling workshops, deal registration process.
    • Resources: Access to sales battlecards, presentation templates, proposal tools.
    • Activity: Shadow a [Your Company] sales rep on a call (if feasible).
    • Certification: "Certified Sales Professional" - pass online exam, deliver mock pitch to PAM.
  • Technical/Pre-Sales Path (Month 1-3):
    • Training: Deep-dive technical training, hands-on labs, implementation best practices, integration protocols and APIs, troubleshooting common issues.
    • Resources: Access to detailed technical documentation, SDKs/APIs, advanced demo scripts, support knowledge base.
    • Activity: Build a sample integration or configure a complex demo in the sandbox.
    • Certification: "Certified Technical Professional" - pass technical exam, successfully complete a practical lab assignment or demo build.
  • Marketing Path (Month 1-2):
    • Training: Brand guidelines, messaging framework, available co-marketing programs & tools, lead management process.
    • Resources: Access to marketing asset library, campaign kits, MDF request process.
    • Activity: Develop a draft joint marketing plan for their first campaign.
    • Certification (Optional): "Certified Marketing Advocate."
  • Key Milestones by End of Month 3:
  • "[X]" number of "Certified Sales Leads" identified and certified.
  • "[Y]" number of "Certified Technical Leads" identified and certified.
  • First internal solution demo successfully delivered by the partner to their PAM.
  • Joint business plan for the next 6-12 months drafted and reviewed.

docs.title: III. Go-to-Market Activation & First Wins (Month 2-6)
docs.text:
• Month 2-4: Pipeline Generation & Co-Selling Practice
  • Action: Register first qualified opportunity in the PRM/CRM.
  • Action: Conduct first joint discovery call with [Your Company] sales team support.
  • Action: Participate in joint pipeline review meetings with PAM.
  • Milestone: First partner-sourced or partner-influenced deal closed. (Celebrate this!)
  • Month 3-6: Joint Marketing & Solution Development
  • Action: Launch first joint marketing activity (e.g., webinar, blog post, local event).
  • Action (for ISVs/SIs): Scope and begin development of first joint solution or integration.
  • Milestone: Measurable ROI from initial marketing activities (e.g., leads generated).
  • Milestone (for ISVs/SIs): Beta version of joint solution ready for demonstration.

docs.title: IV. Ongoing Enablement & Specialization (Quarterly & Annually)
docs.text:
• Quarterly Product Updates & Roadmap Previews:
  • Action: Attend mandatory quarterly product update webinars and roadmap sessions.
  • Milestone: Partner team demonstrates knowledge of new features and positioning.
  • Advanced Workshops & Specializations:
  • Action: Participate in advanced training workshops (e.g., vertical-specific solutions, new product modules, advanced security).
  • Action: Pursue advanced certifications or specializations (if offered by your program).
  • Milestone: Partner achieves "Specialist" status in a key area.
  • Annual Business Review & Planning:
  • Action: Participate in Annual Business Review (ABR) to assess past year performance and plan for the next.
  • Milestone: Mutual agreement on joint goals and investment areas for the upcoming year.
  • Continuous Learning:
  • Access to an updated library of on-demand training, best practice guides, and community forums. (Refer to: Partner Strategy Plan I.5 for community platforms)

docs.title: How to Use & Strategic Implementation:
docs.text:
• Assign a Dedicated Partner Manager (PAM) or Enablement Lead: This individual is responsible for guiding the partner through their roadmap and ensuring accountability.
  • Convert into a Shared Tracking System: Use a collaborative tool (PRM checklist, shared spreadsheet, project management software) to track progress against the roadmap for each key partner. Make it visible to both your team and the partner.
  • Review Progress at QBRs/Regular Check-ins: Make roadmap progress a standard agenda item in Quarterly Business Reviews and other regular partner meetings.
  • Tailor to Partner Type & Tier: While the core framework remains, customize specific activities, timelines, and depth based on the partner's type (e.g., ISV vs. Reseller), tier, and existing capabilities.
  • Celebrate Milestones: Acknowledge and celebrate achievements along the roadmap to maintain motivation and engagement.
  • Feedback Mechanism: Include a way for partners to provide feedback on the enablement process and resources to allow for continuous improvement. (Refer to: Partner Strategy Plan I.5 for formal feedback mechanisms)
  • Link Enablement to Program Benefits: Consider making completion of certain enablement milestones a prerequisite for accessing higher program tier benefits or specific incentives. This drives adoption.

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this template to deliver consistent, comprehensive, and engaging onboarding and refresher training to all partners.

Steps: 1. Review each module and slide prompt. 2. Customize content for your partner type and audience. 3. Add relevant visuals, demos, and proof points. 4. Reference the "Related Templates" for supporting information. 5. Update quarterly and after major program or product changes.

docs.title: Partner Training Deck (Comprehensive & Engaging)
docs.text:
Purpose: To deliver consistent, comprehensive, and engaging onboarding and refresher training to all partners, ensuring they have the foundational knowledge and confidence to effectively represent and sell/service [Your Company]'s solutions.

Core Slides & Enhanced Prompts/Content:

docs.title: Module 1: Welcome & Partnership Overview - Setting the Stage
docs.text:
• Slide 1: Title Slide
  • "[Your Company] Partner Training: Empowering Your Success"
  • Partner Logo (if for a specific partner) or Generic Partner Program Logo
  • Date, Trainer(s) Name(s)
  • Slide 2: Welcome & Introductions
  • Enthusiastic welcome to the [Your Company] Partner Ecosystem.
  • "Meet Your Core Partner Team": Photos, names, roles, and brief descriptions of key contacts (PAM, Partner Marketing, Partner Support Lead, Enablement Lead) and how they support partners.
  • Icebreaker (if live session): Quick introductions from attendees.
  • Slide 3: Our Shared Mission & The Value of This Partnership
  • Briefly reiterate [Your Company]'s mission and the strategic importance of partners in achieving it. (Refer to: Partner Strategy Plan I.5 Vision & Mission)
  • "Why We're Excited to Partner With Companies Like Yours."
  • High-level benefits of the partnership (linking back to their WIIFM).
  • Slide 4: Training Agenda & Objectives
  • Clear outline of topics to be covered in the training.
  • "By the end of this session, you will be able to..." (list 3-5 key learning outcomes).
  • Logistics (breaks, Q&A, duration).

docs.title: Module 2: Understanding [Your Company] & Our Solutions - The Core Knowledge
docs.text:
• Slide 5: [Your Company] Overview: Who We Are
  • Our history, mission, vision, and core values.
  • Our market position, key achievements, and industry recognition.
  • "What makes [Your Company] unique in the marketplace?"
  • Slide 6: Market Opportunity & Target Customers
  • Overview of the target market(s) we address. (Refer to: Partner Business Case I.1 Market Opportunity)
  • Deep dive into our Ideal Customer Profile (ICP): industries, company sizes, pain points, motivations. (Refer to: Ideal Partner Profile I.2)
  • "Who are we selling to, and what keeps them up at night?"
  • Slide 7: Product/Solution Overview: What is [Product Name/Suite]?
  • Clear, concise explanation of your core product(s) or solution suite(s). Avoid excessive jargon.
  • Focus on the problems it solves and the value it delivers to customers.
  • Include a short, engaging demo video (2-3 minutes) showcasing key functionality.
  • Slides 8-9: Key Use Cases & Applications
  • Detail 3-5 primary use cases for your product(s), explaining the "before" and "after" scenarios for customers.
  • Use relatable examples and visuals.
  • Tailor these to the partner type if possible (e.g., use cases relevant for SIs vs. ISVs).
  • Slide 10: Our Technology & Architecture (Simplified)
  • High-level overview of the technology stack, key architectural components, and integration capabilities (especially important for technical partners).
  • Highlight security and compliance features if relevant.

docs.title: Module 3: Winning with [Your Company] - Go-to-Market Strategy
docs.text:
• Slide 11: Compelling Customer Success Stories (Proof We Deliver)
  • Showcase 2-3 diverse and impactful customer win stories (ideally joint wins if applicable).
  • Use recognizable logos where possible.
  • Structure: Customer Challenge -> Our Joint Solution -> Quantifiable Results & Benefits.
  • Include a powerful customer quote if available.
  • Slide 12: Competitive Landscape & Our Differentiation
  • Overview of the main competitors (2-3 max for an intro deck).
  • "How We Win": Clearly articulate your key differentiators against each competitor. (Refer to: Competitive Differentiation Template I.4)
  • Provide a sample talk track or "elevator pitch" for positioning against a key competitor. (Link to more detailed battlecards).
  • Slide 13: Our Sales Process & Partner Engagement Model
  • Overview of your typical sales cycle stages.
  • "How to Co-Sell with [Your Company]": Explain the rules of engagement, deal registration process, and when/how to involve your sales team. (Refer to: Internal Alignment Playbook I.7 RoE)
  • Key points of contact for sales support and deal escalation.
  • Slide 14: Demo Best Practices & Guidance
  • Tips for delivering an effective demo of your solution.
  • Which key features/workflows to highlight for different customer personas or use cases.
  • Where to pause for questions and how to tailor the demo to customer needs.
  • Common pitfalls to avoid during demos.

docs.title: Module 4: Your Partnership Journey & Resources - Ongoing Support
docs.text:
• Slide 15: Navigating the Partner Program
  • Quick recap of program tiers, benefits, and requirements. (Refer to: Partner Program Architecture I.6)
  • How to access specific benefits (e.g., MDF requests, lead registration).
  • Slide 16: Key Partner Resources & Where to Find Them
  • Centralized list of essential resources:
    • Partner Portal Link (and brief overview of its key sections).
    • Sales collateral & marketing asset library.
    • Technical documentation & knowledge base.
    • Training & certification portal.
    • Support contact information & escalation paths.
    • Link to join partner Slack/Teams community or forum. (Refer to: Partner Strategy Plan I.5 for community platforms)
  • Slide 17: Marketing & Co-Marketing Opportunities
  • Overview of available co-marketing programs, resources, and brand guidelines.
  • How to submit a co-marketing proposal or request MDF.
  • Slide 18: Next Steps & Your Enablement Journey
  • Recap key actions for partners post-training (e.g., complete certification, schedule joint business planning).
  • Outline the ongoing enablement roadmap available to them. (Refer to: Partner Enablement Roadmap III.1)
  • Slide 19: Q&A and Feedback
  • Open floor for questions.
  • Encourage feedback on the training session.
  • Slide 20: Thank You & Contact Information
  • Thank partners for their participation and commitment.
  • Reiterate key contact details.

docs.title: How to Use & Enhance Delivery (Expanded):
docs.text:
• Live & Recorded Options: Host live, interactive training sessions (especially for initial onboarding) and also record them for on-demand access. Share the slide deck and video recording as a resource.
  • Modularize Content: Break down longer training into shorter, digestible modules that partners can consume based on their roles or immediate needs.
  • Interactivity: For live sessions, incorporate Q&A, polls, short quizzes, and discussion prompts to keep partners engaged.
  • Role-Play & Practical Exercises: Where appropriate (especially for sales or technical training), include role-playing scenarios or hands-on exercises.
  • Refresh Quarterly & Highlight Changes: Update the training deck at least quarterly to reflect new product features, program updates, or competitive shifts. Clearly highlight what's new.
  • Include a Quick Quiz or Feedback Form: At the end of the training (or each module), include a short knowledge check quiz or a feedback form to assess understanding and gather input for improvement. (Refer to: Partner Strategy Plan I.5 for formal feedback mechanisms)
  • Trainer Enablement: Ensure your internal trainers are experts on the content and skilled presenters. Provide them with a "train-the-trainer" guide.
  • Localize for Global Partners: If you have international partners, consider translating and localizing key training materials.

docs.title: Related Templates
docs.text: • Partner Enablement Roadmap

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this template to design and implement a comprehensive partner certification program that validates competencies, drives enablement adoption, and differentiates high-performing partners.

Steps: 1. Define certification tracks aligned to partner roles and your product portfolio. 2. Establish prerequisites, learning paths, and assessment criteria for each certification. 3. Create the exam/assessment content and passing thresholds. 4. Set up credential management and badge distribution. 5. Link certifications to program tier requirements and benefits.

docs.title: Purpose & Strategic Value
docs.text:
A well-designed certification program serves multiple strategic objectives:

  • Quality Assurance: Ensures partners have validated skills to represent your brand and deliver customer value.
  • Differentiation: Helps certified partners stand out in the market and win more business.
  • Enablement Adoption: Drives completion of training content by making certification a requirement or incentive.
  • Customer Confidence: Provides customers assurance that they're working with qualified partners.
  • Partner Retention: Creates investment and stickiness in the partnership.

docs.title: Program Principles
docs.text:
• Accessible: Training and certification should be available on-demand with clear paths.
  • Relevant: Content must reflect real-world skills needed to succeed with your solutions.
  • Valuable: Certifications should provide tangible benefits (badges, program tier advancement, co-marketing eligibility).
  • Current: Content must be updated regularly to reflect product and market changes.

docs.title: Track 1: Sales Certification
docs.text:
Target Audience: Partner sales representatives and account executives

Levels: | Level | Name | Requirements | Validity | |-------|------|--------------|----------| | Foundation | Certified Sales Associate | Complete Sales 101 training, pass online exam (70%+) | 1 year | | Advanced | Certified Sales Professional | Foundation + Advanced Sales training, mock pitch review | 1 year | | Expert | Certified Sales Expert | Professional + 5 closed deals, case study submission | 2 years |

Learning Path: 1. Product overview and value proposition 2. Target customer profile and pain points 3. Competitive positioning and objection handling 4. Deal registration and co-selling process 5. Pricing and packaging fundamentals

Assessment Format: - Online multiple-choice exam (40 questions, 60 minutes) - Practical: Recorded pitch or live presentation to certification team

docs.title: Track 2: Technical Certification
docs.text:
Target Audience: Solution architects, implementation consultants, technical pre-sales

Levels: | Level | Name | Requirements | Validity | |-------|------|--------------|----------| | Foundation | Certified Technical Associate | Complete Technical 101 training, pass online exam (75%+) | 1 year | | Advanced | Certified Technical Professional | Foundation + hands-on lab completion, architecture review | 1 year | | Expert | Certified Technical Expert | Professional + 3 successful implementations, advanced lab | 2 years |

Learning Path: 1. Architecture and infrastructure fundamentals 2. Installation, configuration, and deployment 3. Integration patterns and API usage 4. Security, compliance, and best practices 5. Troubleshooting and support procedures

Assessment Format: - Online multiple-choice exam (50 questions, 90 minutes) - Practical: Hands-on lab environment assessment - Expert: Architecture design review with certification team

docs.title: Track 3: Delivery/Implementation Certification
docs.text:
Target Audience: Professional services consultants, implementation specialists

Levels: | Level | Name | Requirements | Validity | |-------|------|--------------|----------| | Foundation | Certified Implementation Associate | Technical Foundation + Delivery methodology training | 1 year | | Advanced | Certified Implementation Professional | Associate + 2 supervised implementations | 1 year | | Expert | Certified Implementation Expert | Professional + 5 independent implementations, peer review | 2 years |

Learning Path: 1. Implementation methodology and project phases 2. Requirements gathering and solution design 3. Data migration and integration best practices 4. Testing, QA, and go-live procedures 5. Customer success handoff and documentation

Assessment Format: - Online exam covering methodology and best practices - Practical: Implementation plan review - Expert: Full project documentation and customer reference

docs.title: Track 4: Marketing Certification (Optional)
docs.text:
Target Audience: Partner marketing managers and demand generation specialists

Levels: | Level | Name | Requirements | Validity | |-------|------|--------------|----------| | Foundation | Certified Marketing Advocate | Complete Marketing 101 training, pass online exam | 1 year |

Learning Path: 1. Brand guidelines and messaging framework 2. Co-marketing programs and MDF process 3. Lead management and attribution 4. Campaign best practices and templates

docs.title: 3. Certification Requirements by Partner Tier
docs.text: Partner Tier Sales Certs Required Technical Certs Required Benefits Unlocked Registered None None Portal access, basic training Silver 1 Sales Associate 1 Technical Associate Deal registration, basic support Gold 2 Sales Professional 2 Technical Professional Co-marketing, MDF access, priority support Platinum 3 Sales Professional, 1 Expert 3 Technical Professional, 1 Expert Executive sponsorship, joint solution development

docs.title: Exam Development
docs.text:
• Question Bank: Maintain 3x the number of questions needed per exam for randomization.
  • Review Cycle: Update questions quarterly to reflect product changes.
  • Subject Matter Experts: Involve product, sales, and customer success teams in question development.
  • Beta Testing: Test new exams with internal team before partner launch.

docs.title: Scoring & Passing
docs.text: Certification Level Passing Score Retake Policy Waiting Period Foundation 70% 3 attempts included 7 days between attempts Professional 75% 2 attempts included 14 days between attempts Expert 80% 1 attempt included 30 days between attempts

docs.title: Proctoring Options
docs.text:
• Self-Proctored: Foundation level exams with webcam monitoring
  • Live Proctored: Professional and Expert level exams with remote proctor
  • In-Person: Available at partner events or regional offices

docs.title: Digital Badges
docs.text:
• Issue digital badges via Credly, Accredible, or similar platform
  • Badges should be shareable on LinkedIn, email signatures, and websites
  • Include verification link for customer validation

docs.title: Badge Design Standards
docs.text:
[Badge Elements]
- Certification name and level
- Your company logo
- Issue date and expiration
- Unique verification ID
- QR code for instant verification

docs.title: Certification Directory
docs.text:
• Maintain a public directory of certified partners on your website
  • Allow customers to search by certification type, location, and specialty
  • Include partner contact information and certification details

docs.title: Annual Requirements
docs.text: Certification Level Recertification Requirement Foundation Retake exam OR complete annual update training Professional Complete annual update training + brief assessment Expert Annual update training + demonstrate continued activity

docs.title: Grace Period
docs.text:
• 30-day grace period after expiration for recertification
  • After grace period, must retake full certification path

docs.title: Lapsed Certification
docs.text:
• Notify partner 60, 30, and 7 days before expiration
  • Provide streamlined recertification path for recently lapsed certifications (within 90 days)
  • After 90 days, partner must complete full certification path

docs.title: Roles & Responsibilities
docs.text: Role Responsibilities Certification Program Manager Overall program strategy, content standards, reporting Content Developer Create and maintain training content and exam questions Certification Administrator Process certifications, issue badges, handle exceptions Partner Manager Encourage certification, track partner progress

docs.title: Tracking & Reporting
docs.text:
• Track certification status in PRM/CRM
  • Generate monthly reports on certification completion rates
  • Identify partners at risk of lapsing
  • Measure correlation between certification and partner performance

docs.title: Budget Considerations
docs.text: Item Estimated Cost LMS Platform $X/year Digital Badge Platform $X/year Content Development $X/certification track Proctoring Services $X/exam

docs.title: Internal Readiness
docs.text:
• Training content finalized and loaded in LMS
  • Exam questions developed and tested
  • Badge designs approved and configured
  • PRM integration for tracking
  • Partner Manager training completed

docs.title: Partner Communication
docs.text:
• Announcement email with program overview
  • Detailed certification guide published
  • FAQ document prepared
  • Webinar scheduled to walk through program
  • Support channel established for questions

docs.title: Rollout Timeline
docs.text:
Week 1-2: Internal testing and soft launch with select partners
Week 3-4: Full launch announcement and webinar
Month 2+: Ongoing enrollment and first certification completions
Quarter 2: First recertification cycle begins

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this playbook to establish guidelines, processes, and best practices for joint marketing activities between your company and partners.

Steps: 1. Define your co-marketing program structure and available activities. 2. Establish brand guidelines and approval processes. 3. Set up MDF (Market Development Funds) request and reimbursement workflows. 4. Create campaign templates and asset libraries for partner use. 5. Implement tracking and ROI measurement for all co-marketing activities.

docs.title: Purpose & Value
docs.text:
Co-marketing amplifies reach, shares costs, and builds credibility by combining your brand strength with your partners' market presence and customer relationships.

Benefits for Your Company: - Extended market reach through partner channels - Shared marketing investment and reduced cost per lead - Local market expertise and presence - Increased brand awareness in partner ecosystems

Benefits for Partners: - Access to your marketing resources and expertise - Co-branded content and professional assets - Financial support through MDF programs - Demand generation for their pipeline

docs.title: Program Principles
docs.text:
• Brand Integrity: All co-marketing must adhere to brand guidelines
  • Mutual Benefit: Activities should generate value for both parties
  • Measurable Impact: Track and report on all co-marketing ROI
  • Scalable Process: Standardized workflows that work for all partner tiers

docs.title: Tier 1: Self-Service (All Partners)
docs.text:
Partners can execute independently with provided assets.

Activity Description Support Provided Social Media Share pre-approved posts and content Social toolkit, graphics, copy Blog Syndication Republish approved blog content Blog templates, syndication rights Email Templates Send co-branded emails to their lists Email templates, subject lines Case Studies Share customer success stories Co-branded case study PDFs Product Sheets Distribute solution briefs Co-branded collateral

docs.title: Tier 2: Supported (Silver+ Partners)
docs.text:
Joint activities with your marketing team involvement.

Activity Description Support Provided Webinars Joint educational webinars Promotion, platform, content support Local Events Sponsorship of partner-led events Collateral, speaker support, MDF Content Collaboration Co-authored blogs or whitepapers Writing support, design, promotion Digital Campaigns Joint paid media campaigns Campaign management, creative

docs.title: Tier 3: Strategic (Gold+ Partners)
docs.text:
High-investment, high-visibility joint initiatives.

Activity Description Support Provided Joint Solution Launch Marketing for new joint offerings Full campaign, PR, analyst relations Executive Events C-level roundtables or dinners Event management, executive participation Industry Conferences Joint booth or speaking opportunities Booth space, collateral, staffing Integrated Campaigns Multi-channel demand gen programs Full campaign orchestration

docs.title: Logo Usage
docs.text:
DO:
- Use approved co-branded logo lockups
- Maintain minimum clear space around logos
- Use logos on approved background colors
- Scale logos proportionally

DON'T:
- Alter logo colors or proportions
- Place logos on busy backgrounds
- Use outdated logo versions
- Create unauthorized logo combinations

docs.title: Co-Branding Standards
docs.text: Element Guideline Logo Placement Your logo left, partner logo right (or as specified) Logo Size Equal visual weight for both logos Color Usage Primary brand colors only, no alterations Typography Approved fonts only (provide font files) Imagery Use approved image library or partner-provided

docs.title: Messaging Guidelines
docs.text:
• Always use approved product names and descriptions
  • Include required legal disclaimers and trademarks
  • Avoid comparative claims without approval
  • Submit all external-facing content for review

docs.title: Asset Library Access

docs.title: MDF Program Structure
docs.text: Partner Tier Annual MDF Allocation Funding Model Registered Not eligible - Silver Up to $5,000 50% co-investment Gold Up to $15,000 50% co-investment Platinum Up to $50,000+ 50-75% co-investment

docs.title: Eligible Activities
docs.text:
Approved for MDF: - Joint webinars and virtual events - Local events and trade shows - Digital advertising (PPC, social, display) - Content development (case studies, whitepapers) - Direct mail campaigns - Partner website development (solution pages)

Not Eligible for MDF: - General partner overhead or salaries - Non-marketing travel expenses - Activities not featuring your joint value proposition - Alcohol or entertainment expenses - Activities without lead capture mechanism

docs.title: MDF Request Process
docs.text:
Step 1: Submit Request (30+ days before activity)
        Partner completes MDF request form with:
        - Activity description and objectives
        - Target audience and expected reach
        - Detailed budget breakdown
        - Lead capture and follow-up plan
        - Metrics for success measurement

Step 2: Review & Approval (5-7 business days)
        Partner marketing team reviews for:
        - Strategic alignment
        - Budget appropriateness
        - Brand compliance
        - Expected ROI

Step 3: Execution
        Partner executes activity per approved plan
        Your team provides agreed support

Step 4: Proof of Performance (30 days post-activity)
        Partner submits:
        - Receipts and invoices
        - Screenshots/photos of activity
        - Lead list with required fields
        - Results summary

Step 5: Reimbursement (30 days after POP approval)
        Finance processes reimbursement to partner

docs.title: MDF Request Form Fields
docs.text:
Partner Information:
- Partner company name
- Contact name and email
- Partner tier

Activity Details:
- Activity type (from approved list)
- Activity name/description
- Target audience and geography
- Proposed date(s)
- Expected attendees/reach

Budget:
- Total activity cost
- MDF amount requested
- Partner co-investment amount
- Line-item budget breakdown

Goals & Measurement:
- Number of leads expected
- Other KPIs (registrations, attendees, etc.)
- Follow-up plan for leads generated

Attachments:
- Draft creative/messaging (for review)
- Vendor quotes (if applicable)

docs.title: Playbook 1: Joint Webinar
docs.text:
Timeline: 6-8 weeks

Week Your Team Partner Team 1-2 Define topic, secure speakers Identify target audience, co-speaker 3-4 Create content, landing page Promote to their database 5-6 Set up platform, rehearsal Continue promotion 7 Host webinar Co-present content 8 Send recording, leads to partner Follow up on leads

Success Metrics: - Registrations: 200+ - Attendance rate: 40%+ - Leads generated: 80+ - Pipeline influenced: $X

docs.title: Playbook 2: Local Event
docs.text:
Timeline: 8-12 weeks

Phase Activities Planning Select venue, define agenda, set budget Promotion Email campaigns, social, partner outreach Execution Event logistics, presentations, demos Follow-up Lead distribution, nurture campaigns

Success Metrics: - Attendees: 50+ (varies by event type) - Lead quality: 60%+ fit ICP - Follow-up meetings booked: 10+

docs.title: Playbook 3: Joint Content Campaign
docs.text:
Timeline: 4-6 weeks

Week Activities 1 Define topic, outline, assign sections 2-3 Draft content, internal reviews 4 Design, final approvals 5-6 Publish, promote across channels

Content Types: - Co-authored blog posts - Joint whitepapers or eBooks - Customer case studies - Solution briefs - Infographics

docs.title: Lead Capture Requirements
docs.text: All co-marketing activities must capture: - First name, last name - Company name - Job title - Business email - Phone number (optional but preferred) - Consent for marketing communications

docs.title: Lead Routing
docs.text:
Lead Source          → Routing
-----------------------------------------
Your-hosted webinar  → Your CRM, share with partner
Partner-hosted event → Partner receives first, copy to your CRM
Joint campaign       → Split based on agreed rules

docs.title: Attribution Model
docs.text: Scenario Attribution Partner sources lead, you close Partner-sourced Joint activity generates lead Partner-influenced Your campaign, partner assists close Partner-assisted

docs.title: SLA for Lead Follow-up
docs.text:
• Hot leads: Contact within 24 hours
  • Warm leads: Contact within 48 hours
  • Nurture leads: Add to appropriate nurture track

docs.title: Content Approval Process
docs.text: Content Type Approval Required Turnaround Social posts (templated) None (use as-is) Immediate Email (templated) None (use as-is) Immediate Custom content Partner Marketing Manager 5 business days Press releases PR + Legal 10 business days Customer quotes/logos Customer Success + Legal 5 business days

  2. Partner Marketing Director (budget > $10K or strategic)
  3. VP Marketing (press releases, major campaigns)

docs.title: KPIs to Track
docs.text: Metric Definition Target Leads Generated Total new contacts from activity Activity-specific Cost Per Lead Total spend / leads generated < $100 Pipeline Created $ value of opportunities 5x MDF investment Win Rate % of leads that close Benchmark to direct Partner Engagement % of partners using co-marketing 40%+ of Gold/Platinum

docs.title: Reporting Cadence
docs.text:
• Monthly: Activity summary, leads generated, MDF utilization
  • Quarterly: ROI analysis, top-performing partners, program improvements
  • Annually: Full program review, budget planning, strategy refinement

docs.title: ROI Calculation
docs.text:
Co-Marketing ROI = (Pipeline Created - Total Investment) / Total Investment x 100

Example:
- MDF Spent: $10,000
- Your Additional Investment: $5,000
- Pipeline Created: $150,000
- ROI = ($150,000 - $15,000) / $15,000 x 100 = 900%

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this guide to provide partners with comprehensive technical resources for integrating with your platform, building joint solutions, and delivering successful implementations.

Steps: 1. Customize the technical architecture sections for your specific platform. 2. Document your API endpoints, authentication methods, and data models. 3. Set up sandbox environments and developer resources. 4. Establish integration standards and quality requirements. 5. Create a support escalation path for technical issues.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: This guide provides technical partners with the knowledge and resources needed to successfully integrate with [Your Company]'s platform, build complementary solutions, and deliver high-quality implementations.

docs.title: Integration Types
docs.text: Type Description Typical Partners API Integration Connect systems via REST/GraphQL APIs ISVs, Technology Partners Data Integration Sync data between platforms System Integrators, Data Partners UI/Embed Integration Embed functionality in partner apps ISVs, Platform Partners Workflow Integration Automate cross-platform processes Automation Partners, SIs SSO/Identity Unified authentication All partner types

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Before beginning integration work, partners should have: - [ ] Signed partnership agreement - [ ] Completed Technical 101 certification - [ ] Access to Partner Portal and documentation - [ ] Sandbox/development environment credentials - [ ] Assigned Technical Partner Manager contact

docs.title: Key Components
docs.text: Component Description Partner Relevance API Gateway Central entry point for all API requests Primary integration point Core Services Business logic and processing Understand for data modeling Analytics Engine Reporting and insights Access via API for joint analytics Integration Layer Pre-built connectors Leverage or extend existing integrations Data Layer Persistent storage Understand data models and relationships

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
OAuth 2.0 (Recommended) 

Authorization Flow: Authorization Code Grant

1. Redirect user to authorization endpoint:
   GET https://api.yourcompany.com/oauth/authorize
   ?client_id={client_id}
   &redirect_uri={redirect_uri}
   &response_type=code
   &scope={scopes}

2. Exchange authorization code for tokens:
   POST https://api.yourcompany.com/oauth/token
   Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

   grant_type=authorization_code
   &code={authorization_code}
   &redirect_uri={redirect_uri}
   &client_id={client_id}
   &client_secret={client_secret}

3. Use access token in API requests:
   Authorization: Bearer {access_token}

API Key (Server-to-Server) 

For backend integrations without user context:

Header: X-API-Key: {your_api_key}

Rate Limits:
- Development: 100 requests/minute
- Production: 1,000 requests/minute
- Enterprise: Custom limits available

docs.title: Base URLs
docs.text: Environment URL Production https://api.yourcompany.com/v1 Sandbox https://sandbox-api.yourcompany.com/v1 Documentation https://developers.yourcompany.com

docs.title: Core Endpoints
docs.text:
/users          - User management
/accounts       - Account/organization management
/resources      - Core business objects
/reports        - Analytics and reporting
/webhooks       - Webhook configuration
/integrations   - Integration management

docs.title: Response Format
docs.text:
{
  "success": true,
  "data": {
    "id": "res_123abc",
    "type": "resource",
    "attributes": {
      "name": "Example Resource",
      "created_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
      "updated_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z"
    },
    "relationships": {
      "owner": {
        "id": "usr_456def",
        "type": "user"
      }
    }
  },
  "meta": {
    "request_id": "req_789ghi",
    "rate_limit_remaining": 998
  }
}

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
{
  "success": false,
  "error": {
    "code": "VALIDATION_ERROR",
    "message": "Invalid request parameters",
    "details": [
      {
        "field": "email",
        "message": "Must be a valid email address"
      }
    ]
  },
  "meta": {
    "request_id": "req_789ghi"
  }
}
HTTP Status Error Code Description 400 VALIDATION_ERROR Invalid request parameters 401 AUTHENTICATION_ERROR Invalid or missing credentials 403 AUTHORIZATION_ERROR Insufficient permissions 404 NOT_FOUND Resource not found 429 RATE_LIMITED Too many requests 500 INTERNAL_ERROR Server error (retry with backoff)

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Webhooks enable real-time notifications when events occur in [Your Company]'s platform.

docs.title: Supported Events
docs.text: Event Description Payload resource.created New resource created Full resource object resource.updated Resource modified Changed fields only resource.deleted Resource removed Resource ID user.created New user added User profile integration.status Integration state change Status details

docs.title: Webhook Configuration
docs.text:
POST /webhooks
{
  "url": "https://partner.com/webhook/receiver",
  "events": ["resource.created", "resource.updated"],
  "secret": "whsec_...",
  "active": true
}

docs.title: Webhook Payload Structure
docs.text:
{
  "id": "evt_123abc",
  "type": "resource.created",
  "created_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "data": {
    "object": { ... }
  }
}

Signature Header: X-Webhook-Signature: sha256=...

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
import hmac
import hashlib

def verify_webhook(payload, signature, secret):
    expected = hmac.new(
        secret.encode(),
        payload.encode(),
        hashlib.sha256
    ).hexdigest()
    return hmac.compare_digest(f"sha256={expected}", signature)

docs.title: Pattern 1: Data Synchronization
docs.text:
Use Case: Keep data in sync between [Your Company] and partner systems.

┌─────────────┐         ┌─────────────┐
│   Partner   │◄───────►│    Your     │
│   System    │  Sync   │   Company   │
└─────────────┘         └─────────────┘

Approach:
1. Initial full sync via bulk API
2. Ongoing sync via webhooks + polling
3. Conflict resolution: Last-write-wins or custom logic

Best Practices: - Use idempotency keys for create operations - Implement exponential backoff for retries - Store sync state for resume capability - Handle rate limits gracefully

docs.title: Pattern 2: Embedded Experience
docs.text:
Use Case: Embed [Your Company] functionality within partner application.

┌────────────────────────────────────┐
│        Partner Application         │
│  ┌──────────────────────────────┐  │
│  │   [Your Company] Embed       │  │
│  │   (iframe or component)      │  │
│  └──────────────────────────────┘  │
└────────────────────────────────────┘

Approach:
1. Generate embed token via API
2. Load embed with token
3. Handle postMessage events for interaction

Embed Code Example: 

<iframe
  src="https://embed.yourcompany.com/widget?token={embed_token}"
  width="100%"
  height="600px"
  frameborder="0"
></iframe>

<script>
window.addEventListener('message', (event) => {
  if (event.origin !== 'https://embed.yourcompany.com') return;
  // Handle events from embed
  console.log('Embed event:', event.data);
});
</script>

docs.title: Pattern 3: Workflow Automation
docs.text:
Use Case: Trigger automated workflows across systems.

┌─────────────┐   Webhook   ┌─────────────┐   API Call   ┌─────────────┐
│    Your     │────────────►│   Partner   │─────────────►│   Partner   │
│   Company   │   Event     │  Middleware │   Action     │   System    │
└─────────────┘             └─────────────┘              └─────────────┘

Approach:
1. Subscribe to relevant webhooks
2. Process events in middleware (validate, transform)
3. Execute actions in partner system
4. Optionally update [Your Company] with results

docs.title: Data Protection
docs.text: Requirement Standard Details Encryption in Transit TLS 1.2+ All API communications Encryption at Rest AES-256 For stored credentials Token Storage Secure vault Never log or expose tokens PII Handling Minimize collection Only collect necessary data

docs.title: Authentication Security
docs.text:
• Store client secrets securely (never in code)
  • Rotate API keys annually minimum
  • Use short-lived access tokens (1 hour recommended)
  • Implement refresh token rotation

docs.title: Webhook Security
docs.text:
• Always verify webhook signatures
  • Use HTTPS endpoints only
  • Implement replay protection (check timestamp)
  • Process webhooks asynchronously

docs.title: Compliance Considerations
docs.text: Standard Applicability Partner Requirements SOC 2 All integrations Secure development practices GDPR EU customer data Data processing agreement HIPAA Healthcare data BAA required PCI DSS Payment data PCI compliance if handling cards

docs.title: Integration Certification Requirements
docs.text:
Before going live, integrations must meet:

Functional Requirements: - [ ] All documented API calls work correctly - [ ] Error handling implemented for all scenarios - [ ] Webhook processing is reliable and idempotent - [ ] Data mapping is accurate and complete

Performance Requirements: - [ ] API response handling < 30 seconds timeout - [ ] Webhook acknowledgment < 5 seconds - [ ] Retry logic with exponential backoff - [ ] Graceful degradation on failures

Security Requirements: - [ ] Credentials stored securely - [ ] Webhook signatures verified - [ ] TLS 1.2+ for all connections - [ ] Security review completed

docs.title: Testing Checklist
docs.text:
[ ] Unit tests for API integration code
[ ] Integration tests against sandbox
[ ] Load testing for expected volume
[ ] Error scenario testing
[ ] Security vulnerability scan
[ ] User acceptance testing

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this template to define, track, and communicate key performance indicators for partner success, enabling data-driven decisions and effective partner management.

Steps: 1. Select the metrics most relevant to your partner program goals. 2. Establish baselines and targets for each metric. 3. Set up tracking mechanisms in your PRM/CRM. 4. Create dashboards for internal teams and partner visibility. 5. Review metrics regularly and adjust strategies based on insights.

docs.title: Why Metrics Matter
docs.text:
Effective partner programs are built on clear, measurable outcomes. A robust metrics framework enables you to:

  • Identify top-performing partners for investment
  • Diagnose underperforming partnerships early
  • Demonstrate ROI to leadership
  • Align partner incentives with business goals
  • Optimize program resources and strategies

docs.title: Metrics Categories
docs.text: Category Focus Area Key Question Revenue Financial contribution How much business are partners driving? Pipeline Future opportunity What's the partner-influenced sales funnel? Engagement Program participation Are partners actively involved? Enablement Capability building Are partners equipped to succeed? Satisfaction Relationship health How do partners feel about the program? Operational Efficiency How well are we executing?

docs.title: Primary Revenue KPIs
docs.text: Metric Definition Formula Target Range Partner-Sourced Revenue Revenue from deals originated by partners Sum of closed-won where partner = source 20-40% of total revenue Partner-Influenced Revenue Revenue where partner assisted but didn't source Sum of closed-won where partner involved 30-50% of total revenue Partner Revenue Growth YoY growth in partner-driven revenue (Current year - Prior year) / Prior year 25%+ annually Revenue per Partner Average revenue per active partner Total partner revenue / Active partners $X per partner Partner Attach Rate % of deals with partner involvement Deals with partner / Total deals 40-60%

docs.title: Pipeline KPIs
docs.text: Metric Definition Formula Target Partner-Sourced Pipeline Total value of open opportunities sourced by partners Sum of open opps where partner = source 3x revenue target Pipeline Coverage Ratio Pipeline to quota coverage Partner pipeline / Partner revenue target 3-4x Deal Registration Volume Number of deals registered Count of registrations per period Growth MoM Registration-to-Close Rate % of registered deals that close Closed-won / Total registered 25-35% Average Deal Size Mean value of partner deals Total revenue / Number of deals ≥ Direct deals Sales Cycle Length Time from registration to close Avg days from registration to close ≤ Direct deals

docs.title: Engagement Scoring Model
docs.text:
Partner Engagement Score (0-100)

Component                    Weight    Scoring
─────────────────────────────────────────────────
Portal Activity              20%       0-10 logins/mo = 0-20 pts
Training Completion          20%       % certifications complete
Deal Registration            25%       0-5+ deals/qtr = 0-25 pts
Marketing Participation      15%       Co-marketing activities
Communication Response       10%       Email/call response rate
Event Attendance            10%       Events attended/available

Score Interpretation:
- 80-100: Highly Engaged (invest more)
- 60-79: Engaged (maintain)
- 40-59: At Risk (intervene)
- 0-39: Disengaged (re-evaluate)

docs.title: Enablement KPIs
docs.text: Metric Definition Formula Target Certification Rate % of partners with required certifications Certified partners / Total partners 80%+ for active Training Completion % of assigned training completed Completed modules / Assigned modules 90%+ Time to First Deal Days from onboarding to first registered deal Avg days from activation to first deal < 90 days Ramp Time Time to reach productivity benchmark Days to reach revenue threshold < 180 days Certification Velocity Speed of certification completion Avg days to complete certification < 30 days

docs.title: Partner Satisfaction KPIs
docs.text: Metric Definition Formula Target Partner NPS Net Promoter Score from partner surveys % Promoters - % Detractors 40+ Partner CSAT Satisfaction rating (1-5 scale) Average rating 4.2+ Support Satisfaction Rating of support experience Avg support survey rating 4.5+ Program Satisfaction Overall program rating Annual survey rating 4.0+ Renewal/Retention Rate % of partners renewing agreements Renewed / Eligible for renewal 85%+

docs.title: NPS Survey Framework
docs.text:
Primary Question:
"On a scale of 0-10, how likely are you to recommend our partner
program to another company?"

Follow-up Questions:
1. What is the primary reason for your score?
2. What could we do to improve your experience?
3. What do you value most about our partnership?

Score Breakdown:
- Promoters (9-10): Enthusiastic partners, likely to refer
- Passives (7-8): Satisfied but not enthusiastic
- Detractors (0-6): Unhappy, risk of churn

Survey Cadence: Quarterly pulse + Annual comprehensive

docs.title: Quarterly Review Process
docs.text:
1. PREPARE (Week before)
   - Pull all partner metrics
   - Identify trends and anomalies
   - Draft talking points and recommendations

2. REVIEW (Internal)
   - Team review of partner portfolio
   - Segment partners by health/performance
   - Prioritize intervention targets

3. PARTNER QBR
   - Share performance dashboard
   - Discuss achievements and challenges
   - Align on next quarter priorities
   - Document commitments

4. FOLLOW-UP (Week after)
   - Send QBR summary
   - Create action items
   - Schedule check-ins
   - Update partner plan

docs.title: 2 Weeks Before
docs.text:
• Pull revenue and pipeline data from CRM
  • Gather certification and training status
  • Collect marketing activity results
  • Review open support tickets and escalations
  • Compile win/loss analysis
  • Review last QBR action items

docs.title: 1 Week Before
docs.text:
• Complete draft QBR document
  • Send agenda and pre-read to partner
  • Confirm attendees and logistics
  • Prepare presentation materials
  • Brief internal stakeholders

docs.title: Day of QBR
docs.text:
• Test video/audio if virtual
  • Have backup contact info
  • Bring printed materials (if in-person)
  • Designate note-taker
  • Set up action item tracking

docs.title: Within 48 Hours After
docs.text:
• Send thank you and summary email
  • Distribute meeting notes and action items
  • Update CRM with relevant information
  • Schedule follow-up meetings as needed
  • Enter next QBR on calendar

docs.title: Do's
docs.text:
• Be Data-Driven: Come with facts, not opinions
  • Celebrate Wins: Start positive, acknowledge successes
  • Be Transparent: Share challenges openly, build trust
  • Listen Actively: QBRs should be 50/50 dialogue
  • Focus on Solutions: For every problem, propose options
  • Document Everything: Detailed notes enable accountability
  • Follow Through: Action items without follow-up erode trust

docs.title: Don'ts
docs.text:
• Don't Surprise: Share difficult news before the meeting
  • Don't Lecture: Avoid one-way presentations
  • Don't Skip Prep: Unprepared QBRs waste everyone's time
  • Don't Ignore Elephants: Address tension or issues directly
  • Don't Over-Promise: Set realistic expectations
  • Don't Forget the Relationship: Business aside, maintain connection

docs.title: Common QBR Pitfalls to Avoid
docs.text: Pitfall Impact Prevention Data inconsistency Lost credibility Validate data sources beforehand Too many attendees Unfocused discussion Limit to key stakeholders No executive presence Lack of commitment Require exec sponsors Skipping action review Erodes accountability Always start with last QBR items Running over time Frustrated attendees Strict timekeeping, parking lot

docs.title: When to Use

Situation Template Quarterly board update Board Deck Executive briefing Board Deck Budget approval Board Deck

Pro Tip

Tailor your board deck to highlight revenue impact and strategic alignment. Executives care about numbers and strategy.

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Board members have 5–8 minutes of attention per topic. Lead with what the program has done for revenue. Then show the strategic picture. End with what you need.

Instructions: 1. Complete the KPI table with real numbers before building slides 2. Write the executive summary first — it forces clarity 3. Have finance review revenue figures before presenting 4. Trim ruthlessly — every slide should earn its place

docs.title: Partner Finance Templates
docs.text:
Design partner economics that drive growth.

Finance templates help you structure commissions, rebates, and revenue sharing to incentivize partner performance.

docs.title: Templates
docs.text:
:material-currency-usd: Commission Structure

Tiered commission rates, payment terms, and eligibility criteria for partner-generated sales.

:material-gift: Rebate Program

Volume-based rebate program rewarding partners for hitting revenue milestones.

:material-handshake: Revenue Sharing Model

Revenue sharing model for joint ventures, OEM relationships, and deep technology partnerships.

docs.title: Finance Structure
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[Commission] --> B[Rebate]
    B --> C[Revenue Share]
Model Template Best For Commissions Commission Structure Standard partner-sourced deals Rebates Rebate Program Volume incentives for high performers Revenue Share Revenue Sharing Model Joint ventures and OEM relationships

Finance Best Practice

Start with a simple commission structure and add rebates or revenue sharing as partnerships mature. Communicate changes at least 30 days before they take effect.

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this template to establish a transparent commission structure that incentivizes partners while maintaining healthy margins.

Steps: 1. Define base commission rates 2. Set tier thresholds 3. Establish eligibility requirements 4. Define payment terms 5. Document in partner agreement

docs.title: OVERVIEW
docs.text: This commission structure applies to all authorized partners under the PartnerOS Partner Program. Commission rates are determined by partner tier and deal type.

docs.title: Base Commission Rates
docs.text: Partner Tier Commission Rate Annual Revenue Target Bronze [15]% $0 - $99,999 Silver [20]% $100,000 - $499,999 Gold [25]% $500,000+

docs.title: Tier Qualification Rules
docs.text:
• Tier assessed [quarterly / annually]
  • Must meet [revenue AND certification] requirements
  • Tier valid for [12] months from qualification

docs.title: 1. Partner-Sourced Revenue
docs.text:
Revenue from deals where partner is the primary influence:

Tier Commission Rate Bronze 15% Silver 20% Gold 25%

Eligibility: - Partner must be registered as source in deal registration system - Deal must close within [90] days of registration

docs.title: 2. Partner-Influenced Revenue
docs.text:
Revenue from deals where partner assisted but wasn't primary:

Tier Commission Rate Bronze 7.5% Silver 10% Gold 12.5%

docs.title: 3. Recurring Revenue (SaaS)
docs.text:
For subscription-based products:

Year Commission Rate Year 1 20% Year 2+ 10%

docs.title: 4. Professional Services
docs.text:
For implementation and consulting services:

Service Type Commission Rate Standard Implementation 10% Custom Development 15%

docs.title: Accelerators
docs.text: Revenue Threshold Accelerator 110% of quota +5% bonus 125% of quota +10% bonus 150% of quota +15% bonus

docs.title: New Partner Bonus
docs.text:
• First deal: [+10%] bonus commission
  • First [3] deals: [+5%] bonus per deal

docs.title: Certification Bonus
docs.text:
• [2] certified reps: +2.5% commission
  • [4] certified reps: +5% commission

docs.title: Registration Requirements
docs.text:
• Prospect must not exist in Company CRM
  • Opportunity value > $[minimum]
  • Expected close date within [90] days

docs.title: Protection Period
docs.text:
• Exclusive: [60] days
  • Non-exclusive: [30] days

docs.title: Registration Rewards
docs.text: Scenario Commission Registered + Closed by Partner Standard rate Registered + Partner-assisted Influenced rate Registered + Closed by Company 50% of standard

docs.title: Payment Schedule
docs.text:
• Commissions paid [monthly / quarterly]
  • Payment within [30] days of month-end
  • Minimum payout: $[100]

docs.title: Payment Methods
docs.text:
• Direct deposit
  • Check
  • Wire transfer

docs.title: Payment Documentation
docs.text:
• Commission statement emailed by [X] of each month
  • Detailed breakdown by deal
  • Adjustments from prior periods noted

docs.title: What Counts Toward Revenue
docs.text:
• New logo deals
  • Existing customer expansions
  • Renewals (at standard rate)
  • Professional services

docs.title: What Does NOT Count
docs.text:
• Internal/company deals
  • Competitor replacements (unless approved)
  • Deals below minimum threshold

docs.title: Clawback Provisions
docs.text:
• Cancelled/refunded deals: Commission reclaimed
  • Customer non-payment: Commission reclaimed
  • Deal reversed within [90] days: Commission adjusted

docs.title: Example 1: Bronze Partner
docs.text:
Deal: $50,000 new SaaS subscription
Type: Partner-sourced
Commission: 50,000 × 15% = $7,500

docs.title: Example 2: Gold Partner with Accelerator
docs.text:
Deal: $200,000 new SaaS subscription
Type: Partner-sourced
Annual Revenue: $600,000 (Gold tier)
Base Commission: 200,000 × 25% = $50,000
Accelerator (+5% for 110%+ quota): 200,000 × 5% = $10,000
Total Commission: $60,000

docs.title: Example 3: Influenced Deal
docs.text:
Deal: $100,000 renewal
Type: Partner-influenced
Tier: Silver
Commission: 100,000 × 10% = $10,000

docs.text: Milestone Date Structure approved [Date] Partner communication [Date] System configuration [Date] First commission cycle [Date]

  • Provide training to Partner Account Managers
  • Update partner agreement templates

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: A rebate program supplements base commissions with back-end payments tied to volume milestones — giving partners a reason to consolidate their pipeline with you instead of a competitor.

Steps: 1. Set annual revenue targets for each rebate tier 2. Define rebate percentages (applied to total eligible revenue) 3. Establish the measurement period (calendar year, program year) 4. Communicate 6–8 weeks before program year starts

docs.title: Partner Rebate Program
docs.text: Effective Date: [Date] Program Year: [YYYY] Administered by: [Partner Operations Team]

docs.title: OVERVIEW
docs.text:
The PartnerOS Rebate Program rewards partners who exceed revenue milestones with additional back-end payments. Rebates are calculated on total eligible revenue for the program year and paid within [30] days of year-end close.

Rebates are in addition to standard commissions. They are not a substitute for deal-level commission payments.

docs.title: REBATE TIERS
docs.text: Tier Annual Revenue Rebate Rate Max Payout Silver $100,000 – $249,999 2% $5,000 Gold $250,000 – $499,999 4% $20,000 Platinum $500,000 – $999,999 6% $60,000 Strategic $1,000,000+ 8% Uncapped

docs.title: Rebate Calculation Example
docs.text:
Partner: Acme Corp
Annual eligible revenue: $350,000
Tier: Gold (4% rebate)
Rebate payment: $350,000 × 4% = $14,000

docs.title: To Qualify for a Rebate, Partners Must:
docs.text:
• Maintain active partner agreement throughout the program year
  • Be in good standing (no outstanding compliance issues)
  • Have [1+] certified sales rep on staff
  • Register deals in the partner portal within [5 business days] of engagement
  • Achieve [minimum] [2] new logos in the program year

docs.title: Eligible Revenue
docs.text:
Revenue counts toward the rebate if:

  • Deal was registered and approved in the portal
  • Partner was designated as source or co-sell on the opportunity
  • Deal closed and paid within the program year
  • Customer is not listed as a house account

docs.title: Ineligible Revenue
docs.text:
• Renewals of existing contracts (unless partner sourced original deal)
  • Internal or affiliate transactions
  • Deals below minimum deal size ($[amount])
  • Revenue from suspended or terminated accounts

docs.title: MEASUREMENT PERIOD
docs.text: Event Date Program year start [January 1, YYYY] Mid-year review / progress update [July 15, YYYY] Program year end [December 31, YYYY] Final revenue reconciliation [January 31, YYYY+1] Rebate payment [February 28, YYYY+1]

docs.title: Mid-Year Review
docs.text:
At mid-year, partners receive a progress statement showing:

  • Revenue to date
  • Current projected tier
  • Revenue needed to reach next tier
  • Estimated rebate at current pace

docs.title: PAYMENT PROCESS
docs.text:
1. Revenue report generated by Partner Operations
  2. Partner confirms or disputes within [15 business days]
  3. Disputes resolved within [30 days] via written process
  4. Rebate invoice submitted by partner to [AP email]
  5. Payment issued via [ACH / wire] within [30 days] of invoice

docs.title: Required Documentation
docs.text:
Partners must submit:

  • Signed rebate claim form (provided by Partner Operations)
  • ACH/wire instructions (if updated from prior year)
  • W-9 or equivalent tax form

docs.title: ACCELERATORS
docs.text:
Partners can earn additional rebate percentage for:

Achievement Bonus [3+] new logos (net-new customers) +1% on total rebate [2+] certified technical reps +0.5% on total rebate Completing annual business plan +0.5% on total rebate Co-marketing campaign executed +0.5% on total rebate

Maximum accelerator bonus: +2.5% above base rebate rate

docs.title: PROGRAM RULES
docs.text:
• Rebate percentages are subject to change with [60 days] written notice
  • Program may be terminated with [90 days] notice
  • Rebates not earned in one year do not carry forward
  • Disputes must be submitted in writing within [30 days] of statement date
  • This program does not create an employment relationship

docs.title: CHECKLIST
docs.text:
• Set program year dates
  • Define revenue thresholds per tier
  • Confirm eligible revenue definition with Finance
  • Build tracking view in CRM / PRM
  • Communicate to partners [60 days] before program year
  • Schedule mid-year reviews
  • Set up invoice and payment workflow
