docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Revenue sharing differs from commissions in that both parties are co-owners of the revenue stream, not vendor and referral partner. Use this for OEM/white-label deals, co-built integrations, or joint GTM where both parties invest significantly.

Steps: 1. Define the joint offering or revenue stream 2. Agree on split rationale (investment, risk, ownership) 3. Define attribution and measurement 4. Establish governance cadence

docs.title: Revenue Sharing Model
docs.text: Agreement between: [Company Name] and [Partner Name] Effective Date: [Date] Revenue Stream: [Joint Product / OEM Bundle / White-Label Offering]

docs.title: OVERVIEW
docs.text: This model governs how net revenue from the [Joint Offering Name] is split between [Company] and [Partner]. Both parties contribute to the offering as described below and share in its commercial success accordingly.

docs.title: CONTRIBUTION SUMMARY
docs.text: Party Contribution Revenue Share [Company] [Product, infrastructure, support] [X]% [Partner] [Distribution, customer relationships, services] [Y]% Total 100%

docs.title: Rationale for Split
docs.text:
The [X/Y] split reflects:

  • [Company] provides: [core platform, hosting, tier-1 support]
  • [Partner] provides: [go-to-market, customer success, implementation]
  • Market risk borne by: [Partner / both equally]

docs.title: Gross Revenue
docs.text: Total invoiced amounts for the joint offering, before any deductions.

docs.title: Net Revenue (basis for split)
docs.text:
Gross Revenue minus:

Deduction Amount / Rate Payment processing fees [2.5%] Returns / refunds Actual Taxes collected on behalf of authorities Actual Co-op / MDF funded by [Company] Actual

Split is applied to Net Revenue, not Gross Revenue.

docs.title: Revenue Exclusions
docs.text:
The following are excluded from the shared revenue pool:

  • Professional services billed at full rate by either party independently
  • Support contracts sold separately
  • Hardware / third-party pass-through costs

docs.title: How Revenue Is Attributed
docs.text: Scenario Attributed To Split Applied? Customer sourced by [Partner] [Partner] Yes Customer sourced by [Company] [Company] Yes Inbound / no clear source Shared Yes Renewal of attributed deal Original source Yes Upsell on attributed deal Original source Yes

docs.title: Attribution Rules
docs.text:
• Attribution assigned at opportunity creation in [CRM System]
  • Attribution window: [90] days from first documented contact
  • Disputes escalated to joint governance committee (see below)

docs.title: PAYMENT SCHEDULE
docs.text: Period Revenue Recognized Report Delivered Payment Due Q1 Jan–Mar April 15 April 30 Q2 Apr–Jun July 15 July 30 Q3 Jul–Sep October 15 October 30 Q4 Oct–Dec January 15 January 30

docs.title: Payment Method
docs.text:
• Currency: [USD / EUR / local]
  • Method: [ACH / wire / intercompany]
  • Reconciliation report included with each payment

docs.title: MINIMUM REVENUE COMMITMENTS
docs.text:
Year [Company] Commits [Partner] Commits Year 1 $[amount] $[amount] Year 2 $[amount] $[amount] Year 3 $[amount] $[amount]

Shortfall remedy: If either party misses by >[X]%, a joint remediation plan is required within [30] days. Repeated misses (>[2] consecutive quarters) are grounds for renegotiation or termination.

docs.title: Quarterly Business Review (QBR)
docs.text: Agenda Item Owner Revenue actuals vs. forecast [Company Finance] Attribution reconciliation Both Pipeline review [Partner Sales] Marketing performance [Company Marketing] Issues / disputes Joint

docs.title: Governance Committee
docs.text: Role [Company] [Partner] Executive sponsor [Name/Title] [Name/Title] Alliance lead [Name/Title] [Name/Title] Finance rep [Name/Title] [Name/Title]

docs.title: Dispute Resolution
docs.text:
1. Raise in writing within [15 business days] of revenue report
  2. Alliance leads attempt resolution within [30 days]
  3. Escalate to executive sponsors if unresolved
  4. Binding arbitration if unresolved after [60 days]

docs.title: TERM AND TERMINATION
docs.text: Scenario Notice Required Revenue Sharing Post-Notice Mutual termination [90 days] Continues through notice period Breach by [Company] [30 days] cure period Suspended pending cure Breach by [Partner] [30 days] cure period Suspended pending cure Acquisition of either party [60 days] Continues pending renegotiation

docs.title: CHECKLIST
docs.text:
• Define joint offering scope
  • Agree on revenue split rationale
  • Define Net Revenue deductions
  • Establish attribution rules in CRM
  • Set payment schedule and method
  • Define governance committee and cadence
  • Document in signed addendum to master agreement
  • Configure revenue tracking in finance systems

docs.title: First Partner Onboarding Path
docs.text: The exact 4-week sequence to your first signed partner

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This path guides you from "no partners" to "first partner signed and onboarded" in 4 weeks.

Week Focus Templates Used Week 1 Define & Find IPP, Email Sequence Week 2 Qualify & Pitch Qualification, Discovery, Pitch Week 3 Propose & Sign Proposal, Agreement Week 4 Onboard Onboarding Checklist, Roadmap

docs.text: Goal: Know who you want and find them

docs.title: Day 1-2: Define Your Ideal Partner

Template: Ideal Partner Profile

This defines: - Company size and type - Target market/industry - Technical capabilities - Revenue potential

docs.title: Day 3-4: Build Your Outreach List

Template: Partner Pitch Deck

Customize for top prospect: - Their pain points - Your solution - Partnership benefits

docs.title: Week 3: Propose & Sign

Template: Proposal Template

docs.title: Day 4-5: Negotiate & Verbal Agreement

docs.title: Using the Agent
docs.text:
You can use the AI Agent to help at each step:

cd scripts/partner_agent
python agent.py --playbook recruit --partner "Partner Name"

The agent will guide you through the recruitment playbook, recommending templates and helping customize them.

docs.title: What if I don't have a prospect list?
docs.text: Start with your existing customers who could become partners, or companies you admire in your space.

docs.title: What if prospects say no?
docs.text: Use the Email Sequence follow-ups. Keep building relationships.

docs.title: How long should each week take?
docs.text: This is a guide - adjust based on your timeline. Some companies do this in 2 weeks, others in 8.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
After first partner: 1. Start QBR process - QBR Template 2. Track success - Success Metrics 3. Plan expansion - Expansion Playbook

Follow this path and you'll have a signed, onboarded partner in 4 weeks.

docs.title: How to Use Templates
docs.text: Every template in PartnerOS is designed to be customized for your specific situation. Here's how to get the most out of them.

docs.title: Understanding Placeholders
docs.text:
Templates use placeholders that you'll replace with your information:

Placeholder What to Replace With [Your Company] Your company name [Partner Name] The partner's company name [Product] Your product or solution name $X or $[Amount] Specific dollar amounts [Date] Relevant dates [Name] Person's name [X]% Percentage values

Before & After

Before: 

[Your Company] and [Partner Name] will collaborate to achieve $[X]
in joint revenue by [Date].

After: 

Acme Corp and TechPartners Inc will collaborate to achieve $500,000
in joint revenue by Q4 2025.

docs.title: Level 1: Quick Fill
docs.text:
Just replace the placeholders and use as-is.

Best for: Urgent needs, testing templates, small deals

docs.title: Level 2: Adapt Sections
docs.text:
Keep the structure but modify sections for your context:

  • Remove sections that don't apply
  • Add company-specific sections
  • Adjust language to match your brand voice

Best for: Most use cases

docs.title: Level 3: Deep Customization
docs.text:
Use the template as inspiration to build your own:

  • Reorganize the structure
  • Add your frameworks and methodologies
  • Integrate with your existing documents

Best for: Mature programs with established processes

docs.title: :material-check-circle: Do
docs.text:
• Read the "How to Use" section at the top of each template
  • Customize for your audience - A startup pitch differs from an enterprise pitch
  • Keep it concise - Remove sections you don't need
  • Use your brand voice - Adjust the tone to match your company
  • Version control - Keep your customized templates in Git

docs.title: :material-close-circle: Don't
docs.text:
• Don't use verbatim - Templates are starting points, not final documents
  • Don't over-engineer - Start simple, iterate based on feedback
  • Don't skip sections blindly - Understand why each section exists before removing
  • Don't forget to update - Revisit templates quarterly

docs.title: Template Sections Explained
docs.text: Most templates follow this structure:

docs.title: YAML Frontmatter
docs.text:
---
title: Template Name
description: What this template does
keywords: [search, terms]
---

Used for search and organization. You can remove this in your customized version.

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text: Step-by-step instructions specific to the template. Read this first!

docs.title: Main Content
docs.text: The actual template with sections, tables, and placeholders.

docs.title: Related Templates

1. Copy template content
  2. Paste into a new Google Doc
  3. Use Find & Replace (Ctrl/Cmd + H) for placeholders
  4. Share with your team

1. Create a new page
  2. Paste template content (Notion converts markdown automatically)
  3. Create a template database for reuse

python agent.py --playbook recruit --partner "Acme Corp"

The agent guides you through each template with intelligent prompts.

docs.title: Template Quality Checklist
docs.text:
Before using a customized template, verify:

  • All placeholders replaced
  • Company names and branding correct
  • Dates and numbers accurate
  • Removed irrelevant sections
  • Tone matches your brand
  • Links and references updated
  • Reviewed by a colleague

docs.title: Partner Lifecycle
docs.text:
Every successful partnership follows a predictable lifecycle. PartnerOS provides templates for each phase.

graph TB
    subgraph Strategy
        A[Business Case] --> B[Ideal Partner Profile]
        B --> C[Program Design]
    end

    subgraph Recruitment
        C --> D[Identify & Qualify]
        D --> E[Pitch & Propose]
        E --> F[Sign Agreement]
    end

    subgraph Enablement
        F --> G[Onboard & Train]
        G --> H[Launch & Support]
        H --> I[Measure & Optimize]
    end

    I --> |QBR| H
    I --> |Expand| J[Grow Partnership]
    I --> |Exit| K[Graceful Termination]

docs.title: Phase 1: Strategy
docs.text:
Goal: Define why you need partners and who you're looking for.

Template Purpose Partner Business Case Justify the investment in partnerships Ideal Partner Profile Define your target partner characteristics 3C/4C Evaluation Framework for assessing partner fit Competitive Differentiation Position against competitor programs Partner Strategy Plan Overall partnership strategy document Program Architecture Design tiers, benefits, requirements Internal Alignment Get buy-in across your organization

Start Here

If you're building a partner program from scratch, start with the Business Case to align stakeholders, then define your Ideal Partner Profile.

docs.title: Phase 2: Recruitment
docs.text:
Goal: Find, qualify, and sign the right partners.

Template Purpose Email Sequences Outreach templates for prospecting Outreach Engagement Multi-touch engagement cadence Qualification Framework Score and prioritize prospects Discovery Call Script Structured qualification call Partner Pitch Deck Present your partner program Partnership One-Pager Quick overview for prospects Proposal Template Formal partnership proposal Agreement Template Legal partnership agreement Onboarding Checklist Activation checklist ICP Alignment Tracker Track customer overlap

Typical Recruitment Flow

Outreach → Discovery Call → Pitch → Proposal → Agreement → Onboarding

docs.title: Phase 3: Enablement
docs.text:
Goal: Train, support, and grow successful partners.

Template Purpose Enablement Roadmap Plan partner learning journey Training Deck Core training materials Certification Program Design certification tracks Co-Marketing Playbook Joint marketing activities Technical Integration Integration guidance Success Metrics KPIs and measurement QBR Template Quarterly business reviews

docs.title: Quarterly Business Reviews
docs.text:
Run QBRs to maintain alignment and drive growth:

graph LR
    A[Gather Metrics] --> B[Prepare QBR Doc]
    B --> C[Conduct Meeting]
    C --> D[Action Items]
    D --> E[Follow Up]
    E --> |Next Quarter| A

QBR Template →

When a partnership is thriving, use these to grow:

When it's time to part ways, do it gracefully:

docs.title: Partner Legal Templates
docs.text:
Protect your business with proper legal frameworks.

Legal templates cover the full contract lifecycle from initial NDA through MSA and ongoing compliance.

docs.title: Templates
docs.text:
:material-file-lock: Mutual NDA

Non-disclosure agreement for protecting confidential information during partner discussions.

:material-file-sign: Master Service Agreement

Comprehensive legal and commercial framework for formal partnerships.

:material-shield-lock: Data Processing Agreement

GDPR and privacy compliance framework for partners processing personal data.

:material-clock-check: Service Level Agreement

Support response times, escalation procedures, and service commitments.

docs.title: Contract Flow
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[NDA] --> B[Discovery]
    B --> C[MSA]
    C --> D[DPA]
    C --> E[SLA]
Stage Template When to Use Initial Discussions Mutual NDA Before sharing confidential information Formal Partnership Master Service Agreement When signing a partner Data Sharing Data Processing Agreement When processing personal data Support Commitments Service Level Agreement For Silver and Gold tier partners

Legal Best Practice

Always execute an NDA before sharing confidential business information. Have legal counsel review all agreements before execution.

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this template to create a mutual non-disclosure agreement that protects both parties when sharing confidential business information during partnership discussions.

Steps: 1. Review each section 2. Customize for your company 3. Have legal review 4. Execute with partner 5. Store in partner file

docs.title: PARTIES
docs.text:
This Mutual Non-Disclosure Agreement ("Agreement") is entered into by and between:

Disclosing Party: [Your Company Name] ("Company") Receiving Party: [Partner Company Name] ("Partner")

docs.title: 1. DEFINITION OF CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION
docs.text: "Confidential Information" means any information disclosed by either party to the other, either directly or indirectly, in writing, orally, or by inspection of tangible objects, that is designated as "Confidential," "Proprietary," or some similar designation.

docs.title: 1.1 Examples of Confidential Information include:
docs.text:
• Business strategies and plans
  • Financial information and pricing
  • Customer lists and customer data
  • Technical data and specifications
  • Product roadmaps
  • Pricing models and discount structures
  • Marketing plans and strategies

docs.title: 1.2 Exclusions
docs.text: Confidential Information does not include information that: - Is or becomes publicly available through no fault of the receiving party - Was properly in the possession of the receiving party prior to disclosure - Is independently developed by the receiving party without use of confidential information - Is rightfully obtained from third parties without restriction

docs.title: 2. OBLIGATIONS OF RECEIVING PARTY
docs.text: The Receiving Party agrees to: - Hold Confidential Information in strict confidence - Not disclose Confidential Information to any third parties without prior written consent - Use Confidential Information only for the Purpose stated herein - Protect Confidential Information using the same degree of care used to protect its own confidential information (but no less than reasonable care) - Limit access to Confidential Information to employees and agents who have a need to know

docs.title: 3.1 Duration
docs.text: This Agreement shall remain in effect for [Number] years from the date of execution.

docs.title: 3.2 Survival
docs.text: The confidentiality obligations shall survive termination of this Agreement for a period of [Number] years.

docs.title: 4. RETURN OF MATERIALS
docs.text: Upon termination of this Agreement or upon request, the Receiving Party shall promptly: - Return all tangible materials containing Confidential Information - Destroy all copies of Confidential Information in its possession - Certify in writing that such return and destruction has been completed

docs.title: 5. REMEDIES
docs.text: Each party acknowledges that the other party may suffer irreparable harm in the event of a breach of this Agreement and that monetary damages may be inadequate. Accordingly, either party may seek equitable relief, including injunction and specific performance, in addition to any other remedies available at law.

docs.title: 6.1 Governing Law
docs.text: This Agreement shall be governed by the laws of [State/Country].

docs.title: 6.2 Entire Agreement
docs.text: This Agreement constitutes the entire agreement between the parties concerning the subject matter hereof and supersedes all prior agreements and understandings.

docs.title: 6.3 Amendment
docs.text: This Agreement may only be amended in writing signed by both parties.

docs.title: 6.4 Assignment
docs.text: Neither party may assign this Agreement without the prior written consent of the other party.

docs.title: Checklist
docs.text:
• Customize company names and details
  • Define protection period (typically 2-5 years)
  • Specify governing law jurisdiction
  • Have legal counsel review
  • Execute with signatures
  • Store in partner file
  • Set calendar reminder for renewal

docs.title: Related Templates
docs.text:
• Partnership Agreement
  • Proposal Template
  • Discovery Call Script

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this Master Service Agreement template to establish the legal and commercial framework for a formal partnership.

Steps: 1. Customize all bracketed sections 2. Define partnership terms and conditions 3. Establish payment and commission structures 4. Have legal review 5. Execute with partner

docs.title: PARTIES
docs.text:
This Master Service Agreement ("Agreement") is entered into as of [Date] by and between:

[Your Company Name] ("Company") [Address] [City, State, ZIP]

AND

[Partner Company Name] ("Partner") [Address] [City, State, ZIP]

docs.title: 1. DEFINITIONS
docs.text:
"Services" means the [products/services] provided by Partner to End Customers under this Agreement.

"End Customer" means any third party that purchases Services from Partner.

"Confidential Information" has the meaning set forth in the Mutual NDA executed between the parties.

"Effective Date" means the date first written above.

docs.title: 2.1 Partner Classification
docs.text: Partner is designated as a [Reseller / System Integrator / Strategic Partner] under the [Bronze / Silver / Gold] tier of Company's Partner Program.

docs.title: 2.2 Territory
docs.text: Partner is authorized to promote and sell Services in the following territory: [Global / Specific Countries / Specific Regions]

docs.title: 2.3 Exclusivity
docs.text: [ ] Non-Exclusive: Partner may represent other companies selling competing products. [ ] Exclusive: Partner is the only authorized partner for [specific products/territory].

docs.title: 3. OBLIGATIONS OF PARTNER
docs.text: Partner agrees to:

docs.title: 3.1 Sales and Marketing
docs.text:
• Actively promote and sell Services to End Customers
  • Conduct marketing activities in accordance with Company's guidelines
  • Participate in quarterly business reviews
  • Provide timely forecasts and pipeline reports

docs.title: 3.2 Technical Capabilities
docs.text:
• Maintain qualified technical staff to sell and implement Services
  • Complete required certifications within [90] days of agreement execution
  • Provide first-level support to End Customers

docs.title: 3.3 Compliance
docs.text:
• Comply with all applicable laws and regulations
  • Conduct business in a professional manner consistent with Company's brand
  • Maintain appropriate insurance coverage

docs.title: 4. OBLIGATIONS OF COMPANY
docs.text: Company agrees to:

docs.title: 4.1 Support
docs.text:
• Provide technical support as outlined in Exhibit A
  • Offer training and certification programs
  • Assign a Partner Account Manager

docs.title: 4.2 Resources
docs.text:
• Make available sales and technical materials
  • Provide pre-sales support for opportunities exceeding [threshold]
  • Include Partner in co-marketing activities

docs.title: 4.3 Deal Registration
docs.text:
• Protect registered opportunities for [90] days
  • Not sell directly to registered End Customers during protection period

docs.title: 5.1 Pricing
docs.text: Company shall sell Services to Partner at the prices set forth in Exhibit B (Partner Price List).

docs.title: 5.2 Discount Structure
docs.text: Tier Discount from List Price Bronze [X]% Silver [X]% Gold [X]%

docs.title: 5.3 Payment Terms
docs.text:
• Net [30 / 45 / 60] days from invoice date
  • Late payments subject to [X]% per month interest

docs.title: 5.4 Revenue Share
docs.text: For partner-sourced deals: Partner receives [X]% of net revenue.

docs.title: 6.1 Mutual Representations
docs.text: Each party represents and warrants that: - It is duly organized and in good standing - It has full power and authority to enter into this Agreement - This Agreement constitutes a legal, valid, and binding obligation

docs.title: 6.2 Company Warranties
docs.text: Company warrants that: - Services will perform substantially in accordance with documentation - Company has proper rights to license all software included in Services

docs.title: 6.3 Disclaimer
docs.text: EXCEPT AS EXPRESSLY SET FORTH HEREIN, SERVICES ARE PROVIDED "AS IS."

docs.title: 7.1 Company Indemnification
docs.text: Company shall indemnify Partner against claims that Services infringe third-party intellectual property rights.

docs.title: 7.2 Partner Indemnification
docs.text: Partner shall indemnify Company against claims arising from: - Partner's negligence or misconduct - Misrepresentation of Services to End Customers - Violation of applicable laws

docs.title: 8. LIMITATION OF LIABILITY
docs.text: EXCEPT FOR INDEMNIFICATION OBLIGATIONS, NEITHER PARTY SHALL BE LIABLE FOR ANY INDIRECT, INCIDENTAL, SPECIAL, CONSEQUENTIAL, OR PUNITIVE DAMAGES. TOTAL LIABILITY SHALL NOT EXCEED [Amount].

docs.title: 9.1 Initial Term
docs.text: This Agreement shall be effective for [1 / 2 / 3] year(s) from the Effective Date.

docs.title: 9.2 Renewal
docs.text: This Agreement shall automatically renew for successive [1-year] periods unless either party provides written notice of non-renewal at least [60] days prior to expiration.

docs.title: 9.3 Termination for Cause
docs.text: Either party may terminate this Agreement upon [30] days written notice if the other party: - Materially breaches this Agreement and fails to cure within the notice period - Becomes insolvent or files for bankruptcy

docs.title: 9.4 Effect of Termination
docs.text:
• Partner shall immediately cease representing itself as a Partner
  • Partner shall complete all pending orders within [30] days
  • Confidentiality obligations shall survive termination

docs.title: 10.1 Governing Law
docs.text: This Agreement shall be governed by the laws of [State/Country].

docs.title: 10.2 Dispute Resolution
docs.text: [Mediation / Arbitration] in [City, State/Country].

docs.title: 10.3 Assignment
docs.text: Neither party may assign this Agreement without prior written consent, except to a successor in connection with a merger or sale of substantially all assets.

docs.title: 10.4 Entire Agreement
docs.text: This Agreement, including all Exhibits, constitutes the entire agreement and supersedes all prior agreements.

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this Data Processing Agreement to ensure compliance with GDPR and other privacy regulations when processing personal data.

Steps: 1. Identify data processing activities 2. Customize for specific data types 3. Have legal/privacy team review 4. Execute with partner

docs.title: PARTIES
docs.text:
This Data Processing Agreement ("DPA") is entered into as of [Date] and forms part of the Master Service Agreement dated [MSA Date] between:

[Your Company Name] ("Data Controller" or "Company") AND [Partner Company Name] ("Data Processor" or "Partner")

docs.title: 1. DEFINITIONS
docs.text:
"Personal Data" means any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person as defined under applicable data protection laws (including GDPR).

"Processing" means any operation performed on Personal Data, including collection, storage, modification, disclosure, deletion, or transfer.

"Data Protection Laws" means GDPR, CCPA, and other applicable privacy regulations.

"Sub-processor" means any third party engaged by Partner to process Personal Data.

docs.title: 2.1 Processing Activities
docs.text: Partner shall process Personal Data only for the following purposes: - [Delivery of contracted services] - [Customer support] - [Account management] - [Marketing (with consent)]

docs.title: 2.2 Data Categories
docs.text: Category Examples Contact Data Name, email, phone, address Account Data Company name, job title Usage Data Login timestamps, feature usage Transaction Data Order history, payment info

docs.title: 2.3 Data Subjects
docs.text:
• Customers
  • Leads
  • Employees of End Customers
  • Other: [Specify]

docs.title: 3. OBLIGATIONS OF DATA PROCESSOR
docs.text: Partner shall:

docs.title: 3.1 Processing
docs.text:
• Process Personal Data only on documented instructions from Company
  • Ensure personnel are subject to confidentiality obligations
  • Implement appropriate technical and organizational security measures

docs.title: 3.2 Security Measures
docs.text: Measure Implementation Encryption TLS 1.2+ for data in transit; AES-256 for data at rest Access Control Role-based access, MFA required Logging Audit trails for all data access Incident Response 24-hour notification of breaches

docs.title: 3.3 Sub-Processors
docs.text:
• Partner may engage Sub-processors with prior written consent
  • Partner remains fully liable for Sub-processor compliance
  • Current Sub-processors: [List or attach]

docs.title: 3.4 Data Subject Rights
docs.text: Partner shall assist Company in responding to data subject requests within [30] days: - Access requests - Rectification requests - Erasure requests - Data portability requests - Objection to processing

docs.title: 4.1 Transfers Outside EEA
docs.text: [ ] Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) apply [ ] Adequacy decision in place [ ] Binding Corporate Rules (BCRs) apply

docs.title: 4.2 Transfer Mechanism
docs.text: For transfers outside the EEA, the following safeguards apply: [Describe]

docs.title: 5.1 Notification Timeline
docs.text: Partner shall notify Company within [24-72] hours of becoming aware of any Personal Data breach.

docs.title: 5.2 Notification Contents
docs.text:
• Nature of the breach
  • Categories and approximate number of data subjects affected
  • Likely consequences
  • Measures taken to address the breach

docs.title: 6.1 Audit Rights
docs.text: Company has the right to: - Conduct audits [annually / upon reasonable request] - Request third-party audit reports (SOC 2, ISO 27001) - Review security policies and practices

docs.title: 6.2 Certification
docs.text: Partner maintains: - [ ] SOC 2 Type II - [ ] ISO 27001 - [ ] Other: [Specify]

docs.title: 7.1 Term
docs.text: This DPA shall remain in effect for the duration of the underlying MSA.

docs.title: 7.2 Termination
docs.text: Upon termination, Partner shall: - Delete or return all Personal Data within [30] days - Provide written certification of deletion - Continue to protect Personal Data as required by law

docs.title: 8. LIABILITY
docs.text: Liability under this DPA shall be subject to the limitations set forth in the MSA.

docs.title: 9. GOVERNING LAW
docs.text: This DPA shall be governed by the laws of [State/Country].

docs.title: Appendix: Technical Security Measures
docs.text: [Detail specific security implementations]

docs.title: Appendix: Sub-Processor List
docs.text: [Current list of approved sub-processors]

docs.title: Checklist
docs.text:
• Identify all data processing activities
  • Define data categories and subjects
  • Set appropriate security measures
  • Establish breach notification procedures
  • Define audit rights
  • Have legal/privacy review
  • Execute and store with MSA

docs.title: PARTIES
docs.text:
This Service Level Agreement ("SLA") is entered into as of [Date] and forms part of the Master Service Agreement dated [MSA Date] between:

[Your Company Name] ("Company") AND [Partner Company Name] ("Partner")

docs.title: 1.1 Covered Services
docs.text: This SLA applies to: - [Product/Service Name] - [Product/Service Name] - [API/Integration support]

docs.title: 1.2 Support Hours
docs.text: Tier Support Hours Bronze Business hours (9am-5pm PT, M-F) Silver Business hours + Next business day response Gold 24/7 support with 4-hour response

docs.title: 2.1 Severity Definitions
docs.text: Severity Description Example Critical (P1) Service completely unavailable System down, data loss High (P2) Major feature unavailable Login failure, payment issues Medium (P3) Minor feature impaired UI bug, performance issue Low (P4) General inquiry How-to questions

docs.title: 2.2 Response Time Targets
docs.text: Severity Silver Partner Gold Partner Critical (P1) 8 business hours 4 hours High (P2) 16 business hours 8 hours Medium (P3) 3 business days 1 business day Low (P4) 5 business days 2 business days

docs.title: 2.3 Resolution Targets
docs.text: Severity Target Resolution Time Critical (P1) 24 hours High (P2) 72 hours Medium (P3) 5 business days Low (P4) 10 business days

docs.title: 3.1 Escalation Path
docs.text:
Level 1: Support Team (Tier 1)
    ↓ No resolution in [X] hours
Level 2: Support Manager (Tier 2)
    ↓ No resolution in [X] hours
Level 3: Director of Support
    ↓ No resolution in [X] hours
Level 4: VP of Customer Success

docs.title: 3.2 Escalation Contacts
docs.text: Level Name Title Contact 1 [Name] Support Lead [email/phone] 2 [Name] Support Manager [email/phone] 3 [Name] Support Director [email/phone] 4 VP Customer Success [email/phone]

docs.title: 3.3 Escalation Triggers

• Critical issue unresolved for [4] hours
  • High priority issue unresolved for [24] hours
  • Partner requests escalation

docs.title: 4.1 Credit Structure
docs.text:
If Company fails to meet response time commitments, Partner is eligible for:

Missed Target Service Credit Critical response time 10% of monthly fees High response time 5% of monthly fees 3+ consecutive misses 25% of monthly fees

docs.title: 4.2 Limitations
docs.text:
• Maximum credit: [25]% of monthly fees
  • Credits applied to next billing cycle
  • Exclusions for:
  • Force majeure
  • Partner-caused issues
  • Scheduled maintenance (with 48hr notice)

docs.title: 5.1 Scheduled Maintenance
docs.text:
• Maintenance window: [Sunday 2am-6am PT]
  • Notice period: 48 hours
  • Impact: [Describe typical impact]

docs.title: 5.2 Emergency Maintenance
docs.text:
• May be required for critical security patches
  • Partner notification within [4] hours
  • Best effort to minimize downtime

docs.title: 6.1 Monthly Reports
docs.text: Company shall provide monthly reports including: - Total tickets opened/closed - Average response time by severity - Resolution time metrics - Open issues

docs.title: 6.2 Quarterly Business Review
docs.text: SLA performance reviewed during QBR including: - Trend analysis - Improvement plans - Partner feedback

docs.title: 7. TERM
docs.text: This SLA shall be effective for [1] year from the Effective Date and shall automatically renew unless either party provides [30] days written notice.

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Deal registration gives partners credit — and deal protection — for opportunities they source or develop. A clear policy reduces conflict, increases partner trust, and ensures you capture accurate pipeline attribution.

Steps: 1. Define eligibility criteria (what qualifies for registration) 2. Set protection periods by tier 3. Configure your CRM/PRM to enforce the rules 4. Communicate to all partners during onboarding

docs.title: Deal Registration Policy
docs.text: Effective Date: [Date] Applies to: All authorized partners of [Company Name] Administered by: [Partner Operations]

docs.title: PURPOSE
docs.text: This policy establishes rules for partners to register sales opportunities with [Company], receive deal protection during the sales cycle, and earn appropriate credit upon close.

docs.title: ELIGIBILITY — WHAT QUALIFIES FOR REGISTRATION
docs.text:
A deal is eligible for registration if ALL of the following are true:

  • The prospect is not an existing [Company] customer
  • The prospect is not already registered to another partner
  • The prospect is not an active [Company] direct opportunity (in CRM < [30] days)
  • The expected deal value exceeds $[minimum deal size]
  • Expected close date is within [180] days
  • Partner has had a qualifying interaction with the prospect (meeting, call, demo)

docs.title: Qualifying Interactions
docs.text:
A "qualifying interaction" is documented evidence of partner engagement:

Interaction Qualifies? Discovery call with economic buyer ✅ Yes Demo or proof of concept ✅ Yes Proposal or business case presented ✅ Yes Email chain with prospect only ❌ No Cold prospect list submission ❌ No LinkedIn connection only ❌ No

docs.title: Step 1 — Submit Registration
docs.text:
Partners submit via [Partner Portal / CRM link] within [5 business days] of qualifying interaction.

Required fields: - Company name and primary contact - Estimated deal value - Expected close date - Product / solution of interest - Brief description of opportunity and partner involvement

docs.title: Step 2 — Review and Approval
docs.text: Outcome Timeframe Meaning Approved Within [2] business days Deal protected; partner credited Pending [2–5] business days Under review; do not proceed Rejected Within [2] business days Reason provided; appeal available

docs.title: Step 3 — Protection Begins
docs.text: Protection starts on approval date, not submission date.

docs.title: DEAL PROTECTION PERIODS
docs.text: Partner Tier Protection Period Extension Available? Registered [30] days No Silver [60] days +30 days (request required) Gold [90] days +60 days (automatic if active) Strategic [120] days +90 days (with business justification)

docs.title: Extension Requests
docs.text: Extensions require: - Documented evidence of continued active engagement - Updated close date from prospect - Submitted to [partner-ops@company.com] at least [5] business days before expiration

docs.title: COMMISSION / CREDIT ON REGISTERED DEALS
docs.text: Scenario Credit Partner sources AND closes the deal Full partner-sourced commission Partner sources, [Company] assists in close Partner-sourced commission Partner sources, [Company] closes independently [50%] of partner-sourced commission Registration expires, [Company] closes later No credit (re-registration required)

docs.title: When Two Partners Register the Same Prospect
docs.text:
1. First registration wins — approval timestamp is determinative
  2. Second partner notified within [2] business days
  3. If registered within [24 hours] of each other:
  4. Both parties contacted
  5. [Company] determines primary partner based on evidence of engagement
  6. Decision is final and communicated within [5] business days

docs.title: When [Company] Direct and Partner Conflict
docs.text:
• If [Company] has active opportunity (in CRM > [30] days): direct team wins
  • If [Company] opportunity < [30] days old at time of partner registration: co-sell required
  • If [Company] has no prior activity: partner wins

docs.title: PROHIBITED PRACTICES
docs.text:
Partners may NOT:

  • Register competitors, inactive prospects, or speculative targets without engagement
  • Register prospects they have not directly engaged
  • Submit bulk registrations without qualifying interactions
  • Share deal registration approvals with unaffiliated third parties

Violations may result in registration cancellation, commission forfeiture, or partner agreement termination.

docs.title: APPEALS PROCESS
docs.text:
1. Submit written appeal to [partner-ops@company.com] within [10 business days]
  2. Include supporting evidence (emails, meeting notes, call logs)
  3. Decision within [15 business days]
  4. Appeals reviewed by Partner Operations Director; decision is final

docs.title: CHECKLIST
docs.text:
• Set minimum deal size threshold
  • Configure partner portal for deal registration
  • Train PAMs on conflict resolution process
  • Publish policy in partner portal
  • Add to partner onboarding packet
  • Build CRM view for registered deal tracking

Portal: [PRM System Name] URL: [https://partners.yourcompany.com] Version: 1.0 | [Date] Support contact: [partner-ops@company.com]

Welcome to the [Company] Partner Portal — your hub for deal registration, collateral, training, and program resources. This guide gets you productive in under 30 minutes.

docs.title: Qualification Criteria
docs.text:
Before investing time in a prospect, verify:

  • Matches Ideal Partner Profile
  • Passes 3C/4C Evaluation
  • Has executive sponsor
  • Willing to commit resources
  • Strategic fit confirmed

Common Mistakes

  • Recruiting partners who don't match your ICP
  • Skipping qualification to hit partner count goals
  • Not involving partner's executive sponsor early

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this template to create a systematic, professional email sequence for recruiting potential partners.

Steps: 1. Customize each email for your target partner 2. Set up proper timing between emails 3. Track responses and engagement 4. Adjust sequence based on partner type 5. Follow up appropriately

docs.title: Subject Line Options
docs.text:
• "Partnering with [Your Company] to [Value Proposition]"
  • "Join [Your Company]'s Partner Ecosystem"
  • "Transform [Industry] with [Your Company]"
  • "Strategic Partnership Opportunity: [Your Company]"
  • "Let's Discuss a Partnership: [Your Company]"

docs.title: Email Template
docs.text:
Dear [Partner Name],

I hope this email finds you well. I'm reaching out because I've been impressed by [specific achievement or strength of their company] and believe there's a strong alignment between our organizations.

[Your Company] is [brief value proposition - e.g., "revolutionizing how companies manage their data infrastructure"], and we're looking to partner with innovative companies like [Partner Company] to [specific goal - e.g., "expand our reach in the enterprise market"].

What caught my attention:
- [Specific achievement or strength #1]
- [Specific achievement or strength #2]
- [Specific achievement or strength #3]

Would you be open to a brief conversation to explore how we might create mutual value through a partnership?

Best regards,
[Your Name]
[Your Position]
[Your Company]

docs.title: Subject Line Options
docs.text:
• "Following up: [Your Company] Partnership"
  • "Quick question about [Industry]"
  • "Re: [Previous Subject]"
  • "Thought you might be interested in this"
  • "Adding value to [Partner's Market]"

docs.title: Email Template
docs.text:
Hi [Partner Name],

I wanted to follow up on my previous email about a potential partnership between [Your Company] and [Partner Company].

I thought you might be particularly interested in how we've helped companies like [relevant customer] achieve [specific outcome].

Would you have 15 minutes this week to discuss how we might create similar value together?

Best regards,
[Your Name]

docs.title: Subject Line Options
docs.text:
• "How [Your Company] + [Partner Company] = [Value]"
  • "Creating [Value] Together"
  • "Partnership Opportunity: [Specific Benefit]"
  • "Transforming [Industry] Together"
  • "Strategic Alliance: [Value Proposition]"

docs.title: Email Template
docs.text:
Hi [Partner Name],

I understand you're busy, but I wanted to share a specific example of how a partnership between [Your Company] and [Partner Company] could create significant value:

[Specific value proposition with data points or case studies]

Key benefits for [Partner Company]:
- [Benefit #1]
- [Benefit #2]
- [Benefit #3]

Would you be interested in learning more about how we could achieve similar results together?

Best regards,
[Your Name]

docs.title: Subject Line Options
docs.text:
• "Last attempt: [Your Company] Partnership"
  • "Final note: [Value Proposition]"
  • "Closing the loop on [Partnership Idea]"
  • "One last thought about [Industry]"
  • "Wrapping up: [Your Company] + [Partner Company]"

docs.title: Email Template
docs.text:
Hi [Partner Name],

I wanted to send one final note about the potential partnership between [Your Company] and [Partner Company].

I understand if the timing isn't right, but I believe there's significant value in exploring how we could work together to [specific goal or value proposition].

If you're interested in learning more, I'm happy to:
- Share more detailed information
- Connect you with relevant team members
- Discuss specific partnership models
- Explore potential opportunities

No pressure, but I'd appreciate a quick response either way.

Best regards,
[Your Name]

docs.title: Positive Response
docs.text:
Thank you for your interest! I'd be happy to schedule a call to discuss this further.

[Your Company] has several partnership models that might be of interest:
1. [Model #1]
2. [Model #2]
3. [Model #3]

Would you prefer to:
- Schedule a discovery call
- Receive more information
- Meet with specific team members
- Discuss particular aspects

Let me know your preference, and I'll make the necessary arrangements.

Best regards,
[Your Name]

docs.title: No Response
docs.text:
Hi [Partner Name],

I understand you're busy, but I wanted to check if you had a chance to review my previous emails about a potential partnership between [Your Company] and [Partner Company].

If you're not interested, I completely understand. A quick "no thanks" would help me close the loop.

If you are interested but haven't had time to respond, I'm happy to:
- Send more information
- Schedule a call at your convenience
- Connect you with relevant team members

Best regards,
[Your Name]

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this template to conduct structured, effective discovery calls that gather key information and build relationships with potential partners.

Steps: 1. Prepare using the pre-call checklist 2. Follow the call structure 3. Use the question bank 4. Document key information 5. Plan next steps

docs.title: Strategic Purpose
docs.text: This script is designed to help you effectively qualify a prospective partner, gather critical information for segmentation and Ideal Partner Profile (IPP) alignment, assess mutual interest, and determine appropriate next steps. Use this as a structured conversation guide, not an interrogation.

docs.title: Research Checklist
docs.text:
• Company overview
  • Recent news
  • Leadership team
  • Market position
  • Potential synergies
  • Previous interactions
  • Mutual connections
  • Industry context

docs.title: Call Objectives
docs.text:
• Understand partner's business
  • Identify potential value
  • Assess strategic fit
  • Explore partnership interest
  • Determine next steps

docs.title: Required Materials
docs.text:
• Call script
  • Company information
  • Partnership overview
  • Value proposition
  • Next steps plan

docs.title: Introduction (2-3 minutes)
docs.text:
"Hi [Name], thanks for taking the time to meet today. I'm [Your Name] from [Your Company], and I'm excited to learn more about [Partner Company] and explore how we might work together.

Before we dive in, I'd like to:
1. Confirm we have 30 minutes for our discussion
2. Share a brief overview of [Your Company]
3. Learn more about [Partner Company]
4. Explore potential partnership opportunities

Does that agenda work for you?"

docs.title: Company Overview (5-7 minutes)
docs.text:
"[Your Company] is [brief value proposition]. We help [target customers] achieve [specific outcomes] through [key solutions].

What I find particularly interesting about [Partner Company] is [specific observation or potential synergy]."

docs.title: Partner Discussion (10-15 minutes)
docs.text:
• Use question bank
  • Listen actively
  • Take notes
  • Identify opportunities
  • Build rapport

docs.title: Partnership Discussion (5-7 minutes)
docs.text:
• Share partnership models
  • Discuss potential value
  • Address questions
  • Gauge interest
  • Identify next steps

docs.title: Closing (2-3 minutes)
docs.text:
• Summarize key points
  • Confirm next steps
  • Set timeline
  • Express appreciation
  • End professionally

docs.title: Company Understanding
docs.text:
1. "Could you tell me about [Partner Company]'s journey and current focus?"
  2. "What are your key products/services and target markets?"
  3. "How do you differentiate in your market?"
  4. "What are your growth priorities for the next 12-18 months?"
  5. "What challenges are you currently facing?"

docs.title: Market Position
docs.text:
1. "How do you position yourself in the market?"
  2. "Who are your primary competitors?"
  3. "What's your market share in key segments?"
  4. "How do you approach market expansion?"
  5. "What trends are impacting your business?"

docs.title: Partnership Experience
docs.text:
1. "What types of partnerships have you pursued in the past?"
  2. "What's been most successful for you?"
  3. "What challenges have you faced?"
  4. "How do you measure partnership success?"
  5. "What's your ideal partnership model?"

docs.title: Technical Capabilities
docs.text:
1. "What's your technology stack?"
  2. "How do you handle integration?"
  3. "What's your development process?"
  4. "How do you ensure security?"
  5. "What's your support model?"

docs.title: Business Operations
docs.text:
1. "How is your sales team structured?"
  2. "What's your go-to-market approach?"
  3. "How do you handle customer success?"
  4. "What's your project management methodology?"
  5. "How do you measure success?"

docs.title: Key Qualification Criteria
docs.text:
• Alignment with Ideal Partner Profile (see ICP Alignment Tracker)
  • Complementary solutions, market reach, or technical capabilities
  • Willingness and ability to invest in partnership
  • Executive sponsorship and decision-maker engagement
  • Clear mutual value and opportunity for joint wins

docs.title: Next Steps Guidance
docs.text:
• If qualified: Schedule a follow-up deep-dive, share NDA, and begin formal application or proposal process.
  • If not a fit: Thank them for their time, provide feedback, and keep the door open for future opportunities.
  • Always document key findings and update your PRM or tracking system.

docs.title: Common Objections
docs.text:
1. Timing
  2. "We're focused on other priorities"
  3. "It's not the right time"

  4. "We need to complete current initiatives"

  5. Resources

  6. "We don't have the bandwidth"
  7. "Our team is already stretched"

  8. "We need to hire more people"

  9. Value

  10. "We're not seeing the ROI"
  11. "The market isn't ready"

  12. "Our customers aren't asking for this"

  13. Competition

  14. "We're already working with [competitor]"
  15. "We have our own solution"
  16. "The market is too crowded"

docs.title: Response Strategies
docs.text:
1. Acknowledge
  2. "I understand your concern"
  3. "That's a valid point"

  4. "I appreciate your perspective"

  5. Explore

  6. "Could you tell me more about that?"
  7. "What would make this more valuable?"

  8. "How could we address this?"

  9. Address

  10. Share relevant examples
  11. Provide data points

  12. Offer solutions

  13. Move Forward

  14. Suggest next steps
  15. Offer alternatives
  16. Set follow-up

docs.text:
• Company details
  • Key contacts
  • Decision makers
  • Timeline
  • Budget
  • Requirements
  • Concerns
  • Next steps

docs.title: 7. Best Practices & Pro Tips
docs.text:
• Build Rapport: Start with genuine curiosity and respect for the partner's business.
  • Listen Actively: Let the partner speak 60–70% of the time; use open-ended questions.
  • Document Diligently: Capture key points, opportunities, and challenges in your PRM or CRM.
  • Be Transparent: Clearly outline your program's requirements, expectations, and next steps.
  • Follow Up Promptly: Send a summary email with agreed next steps within 24 hours.
  • Continuous Improvement: After each call, review what worked and refine your approach.

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  [YOUR LOGO]                              [PARTNER PROGRAM] │
│                                                             │
│        GROW FASTER WITH [YOUR COMPANY]                      │
│           Partner Program                                   │
│                                                             │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Elements: - Your company logo (high resolution) - Partner program name/badge - Compelling headline that speaks to partner outcomes - Optional: Partner's logo if customizing for specific partner

docs.title: Section 2: Program Overview (2-3 sentences)
docs.text:
Template:

[Your Company] partners with industry-leading [partner types] to deliver [outcome] for [target customers]. Our partner program provides [key benefit 1], [key benefit 2], and [key benefit 3] to help you [partner outcome].

Example:

Acme partners with leading technology consultants to deliver digital transformation for mid-market enterprises. Our partner program provides technical enablement, co-selling support, and generous margins to help you grow your practice and delight your customers.

docs.title: Section 3: Key Benefits (3-5 bullets)
docs.text:
Format each benefit as: Icon + Benefit Title + One-line description

Icon Benefit Description 💰 Attractive Economics Competitive margins up to X% plus deal registration bonuses 🎯 Lead Sharing Qualified leads in your territory delivered to your pipeline 🛠️ Technical Enablement Free training, certifications, and sandbox environments 📣 Co-Marketing Support MDF funds, co-branded assets, and joint campaign support 🤝 Dedicated Support Named partner manager and priority technical assistance

docs.title: Section 4: How It Works
docs.text:
Visual Journey (3-4 steps):

    ┌─────────┐      ┌─────────┐      ┌─────────┐      ┌─────────┐
    │  APPLY  │ ──▶  │ ONBOARD │ ──▶  │  ENABLE │ ──▶  │  GROW   │
    └─────────┘      └─────────┘      └─────────┘      └─────────┘
    Complete our      Access portal    Complete         Start selling
    simple online     and training     certification    and earning
    application       resources        requirements     together

Detailed Steps: 1. Apply - Complete our online application (5 minutes) 2. Onboard - Access partner portal, sign agreement, meet your PAM 3. Enable - Complete required training and get certified 4. Grow - Register deals, access resources, earn revenue

docs.title: Section 5: Program Tiers (if applicable)
docs.text: Tier Requirements Key Benefits Registered Sign up Portal access, basic training Silver $50K revenue, 1 cert 20% margin, MDF access Gold $200K revenue, 3 certs 25% margin, leads, dedicated PAM Platinum $500K+ revenue, 5 certs 30% margin, executive sponsor, custom programs

docs.title: Section 6: Proof Points
docs.text:
Choose 2-3 compelling stats or quotes:

Option A: Statistics 

┌─────────────────┐  ┌─────────────────┐  ┌─────────────────┐
│      150+       │  │       35%       │  │       $2M+      │
│    Partners     │  │   Faster Deal   │  │  Partner Revenue│
│   Worldwide     │  │     Cycles      │  │    Last Year    │
└─────────────────┘  └─────────────────┘  └─────────────────┘

Option B: Testimonial

"Partnering with [Your Company] helped us grow our practice by 40% in the first year. The enablement resources and co-selling support made all the difference." — [Name], [Title], [Partner Company]

Option C: Case Study Snippet

[Partner Name] increased their average deal size by 2.5x after joining our program, closing $1.2M in joint revenue in Q1 alone.

docs.title: Section 7: Call to Action
docs.text:
Primary CTA: 

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                             │

│                                                             │
│     📧 partners@yourcompany.com                            │
│     🌐 yourcompany.com/partners                            │

Elements to include: - Partner program email - Partner portal URL - QR code linking to application - Social media handles (optional) - Partner manager contact (if sending to specific prospect)

docs.text: Partner Type Emphasize Adjust Language Resellers Margins, deal registration Revenue, sales enablement System Integrators Technical training, certifications Implementation, services Technology Partners Integration support, API access Joint solutions, roadmap Referral Partners Referral fees, simplicity Easy process, quick payouts

docs.title: By Event/Context
docs.text:

  • Executive Meeting: Sophisticated, ROI-focused
  • Cold Outreach: Problem-focused, clear next steps
  • Partner Referral: Warm intro, relationship-based

docs.title: Do's
docs.text:
• ✅ Keep it to ONE page (front only, or front/back max)
  • ✅ Use your brand colors and fonts consistently
  • ✅ Include plenty of white space
  • ✅ Use icons and visuals to break up text
  • ✅ Make the CTA prominent and easy to act on
  • ✅ Proofread carefully—this represents your brand

docs.title: Don'ts
docs.text:
• ❌ Don't use tiny fonts to fit more content
  • ❌ Don't include every program detail
  • ❌ Don't use jargon or internal terminology
  • ❌ Don't forget contact information
  • ❌ Don't make it text-heavy—keep it scannable

docs.text: Format Use Case Notes PDF Email attachment, downloads Most versatile PNG/JPG Social media, presentations Single image version Print Trade shows, meetings High-quality paper stock Interactive PDF Digital distribution Clickable links, QR codes

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this checklist to operationalize and streamline the ramp-up process for new partners.

Steps: 1. Review each phase and action item. 2. Assign owners and due dates for each task. 3. Track completion in your PRM or project management tool. 4. Reference the "Related Templates" for supporting information. 5. Review progress at key milestones and refine as needed.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This checklist is designed to operationalize and streamline the ramp-up process for new partners, ensuring all critical legal, technical, go-to-market (GTM), and communication steps are completed efficiently for a "ready to engage and transact" status. The process is phased over the first 90 days, with clear milestones and best practices.

docs.title: 1. Legal & Contracting (Target: Day 1–7)
docs.text:
• Mutual Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA) executed.
  • Partner Program Agreement (MSA/Terms & Conditions) reviewed, negotiated (if applicable), and signed by authorized signatories from both parties.
  • Partner profile fully completed in PRM/CRM with all legal entity details.

docs.title: 2. Technical & Portal Setup (Target: Day 1–14)
docs.text:
• Partner contacts provisioned with access to Partner Portal, PRM, and essential tools.
  • Partner profile and contacts validated in all relevant systems.
  • Introduction to key tools for deal registration, MDF requests, support tickets.

docs.title: 3. Initial Enablement & Program Immersion (Target: Day 7–21)
docs.text:
• Welcome & Program Overview session scheduled and attended.
  • Introduction to the core partner team and their roles.
  • Detailed overview of the partner program (tiers, benefits, requirements, rules of engagement).
  • Review of key resources available in the portal.
  • Initial product/solution training scheduled (sales and/or technical enablement).
  • Key enablement resources shared and reviewed (training materials, product docs, battlecards, demo scripts).

docs.title: 4. Go-to-Market (GTM) Alignment & Planning (Target: Day 21–45)
docs.text:
• ICP & target account list exchange and review (identify overlaps and net-new opportunities).
  • Joint GTM planning session scheduled and conducted.
  • Define initial joint value proposition and 1–2 target use cases/solutions.
  • Outline a basic 90-day GTM plan with specific activities and goals.
  • Agree on success metrics for the first 90–180 days.
  • Introduction to relevant internal sales/CS teams (AEs, SEs, CSMs).

docs.title: 5. Communications & Internal Integration (Ongoing, kickoff Day 1–15)
docs.text:
• Official welcome email from executive sponsor sent to partner.
  • Introduction of dedicated Partner Manager (PAM) / key contact.
  • Addition to partner communication channels (Slack/Teams, email lists, etc.).
  • Internal announcement of new partnership to relevant teams (sales, marketing, CS).

docs.title: 6. Marketing & Visibility Setup (Target: Day 30–60)
docs.text:
• Marketing starter kit delivered and reviewed (logos, messaging, solution descriptions, social templates).
  • Partner logo & profile added to your website/partner directory (as applicable).
  • Initial co-marketing brainstorm/discussion (e.g., joint blog post, webinar).

docs.title: 7. First Opportunity & Pipeline Development (Target: Day 60–90)
docs.text:
• Identify/register first pipeline deal or co-sell activity.
  • Support for first joint customer engagement (e.g., SE for demo, joint call with AE).
  • Joint pipeline review cadence established (recurring meetings).

docs.title: 8. Review & Refine (Target: Day 90)
docs.text:
• Schedule first Quarterly Business Review (QBR) or check-in.
  • Gather feedback from the partner on the onboarding experience.
  • Identify early challenges or areas for improvement.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Track Progress Systematically: Use your PRM, a shared project management tool, or a collaborative document to track completion. Assign owners and due dates for each task.
  • Dynamic Review Cadence: Review progress at key milestones (30/60/90 day health checks) with the partner and internally.
  • Tailor to Partner Type: Customize the checklist and timeline based on partner type (e.g., ISV onboarding will have different technical steps than a referral partner).
  • Assign an Onboarding "Buddy" or Lead: Designate an internal person responsible for guiding the partner through onboarding.
  • Celebrate Milestones: Acknowledge and celebrate completion of key onboarding milestones (e.g., first certification, first registered deal).
  • Feedback Loop: Continuously refine the onboarding checklist and process based on feedback from new partners and internal teams.

docs.title: Do's
docs.text:
• Start with a focused list (20-50 accounts max)
  • Prioritize based on fit AND likelihood of joint success
  • Establish clear ownership and engagement rules upfront
  • Track all touchpoints in a shared system
  • Celebrate wins together to build momentum

docs.title: Don'ts
docs.text:
• Don't share sensitive account data without proper agreements
  • Don't pursue accounts without partner alignment
  • Don't let the list go stale—refresh regularly
  • Don't ignore account conflicts—address them early
  • Don't measure only pipeline—track engagement quality too

docs.title: Glossary of Key Terms
docs.text: title: Appendix I: Glossary of Key Terms keywords: ["appendix i glossary", "service cloud services", "delivering educational courses", "engagement roi return", "wiifp what s", "formal review"]

docs.title: Appendix I: Glossary of Key Terms
docs.text:
• ABC: Anti-Bribery and Corruption.
  • ABR: Annual Business Review. A formal review with a partner to discuss past year performance and plan for the next.
  • AE: Account Executive.
  • ARR: Annual Recurring Revenue. The value of contracted recurring revenue normalized to one year.
  • BI: Business Intelligence.
  • CAGR: Compound Annual Growth Rate.
  • CLTV: Customer Lifetime Value.
  • CRM: Customer Relationship Management. A system for managing interactions with current and potential customers.
  • CS: Customer Success.
  • CSAT: Customer Satisfaction Score.
  • CSM: Customer Success Manager.
  • CTA: Call to Action.
  • FSI: Financial Services Industry.
  • GTM: Go-to-Market. The strategy for how a company will reach target customers and achieve competitive advantage.
  • ICP: Ideal Customer Profile. A description of the perfect customer for your solution.
  • IP: Intellectual Property.
  • iPaaS: Integration Platform as a Service. Cloud services for connecting applications and data.
  • ISV: Independent Software Vendor. A company that makes and sells software products.
  • KPI: Key Performance Indicator. A measurable value demonstrating how effectively a company is achieving key business objectives.
  • LMS: Learning Management System. Software for administering and delivering educational courses or training programs.
  • MAP: Marketing Automation Platform.
  • MDF: Marketing Development Funds provided to partners for sales and marketing activities.
  • MSA: Master Service Agreement.
  • NDA: Non-Disclosure Agreement.
  • NPS: Net Promoter Score.
  • OEM: Original Equipment Manufacturer. Supplies components used in another company's products.
  • OKR: Objectives and Key Results. A goal-setting framework.
  • PAC: Partner Advisory Council.
  • PAM: Partner Account Manager.
  • POC: Proof of Concept or Point of Contact.
  • PRM: Partner Relationship Management. Tools and processes for managing partner relationships.
  • PSAT: Partner Satisfaction Score.
  • PSA: Professional Services Automation.
  • QBR: Quarterly Business Review.
  • RoE: Rules of Engagement.
  • ROI: Return on Investment.
  • SAM: Serviceable Addressable Market.
  • SE: Sales Engineer or Solutions Engineer.
  • SI: System Integrator.
  • SLA: Service Level Agreement.
  • SMART: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound (for goals/KRs).
  • SMB: Small and Medium-sized Business.
  • SOM: Serviceable Obtainable Market (or Share of Market).
  • SWOT: Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats (analysis).
  • TAM: Total Addressable Market.
  • TCO: Total Cost of Ownership.
  • UVP: Unique Value Proposition.
  • VAR: Value-Added Reseller.
  • WIIFM: What's In It For Me? (or WIIFP - What's In It For Partner?)

docs.title: Maturity Model
docs.text: title: Appendix II: Conceptual Partner Program Maturity Model keywords: ["often opportunistic driven", "partners early attempts", "joint marketing kpis", "refined deeper dives", "product training available", "partner community engagement"]

docs.title: Appendix II: Conceptual Partner Program Maturity Model
docs.text:
This model provides a framework for understanding the evolution of a partner program and helps identify which areas of this blueprint to prioritize based on your current stage.

Stage 1: Foundational (Ad-hoc & Reactive) * Characteristics: * Partnerships are often opportunistic, driven by individual relationships. * Limited formal processes or dedicated resources. * Basic partner agreements (NDA, referral agreement). * Success is inconsistently tracked, if at all. * Little to no specific partner enablement. * Blueprint Focus: * Partner Business Case (I.1) - To justify investment. * Ideal Partner Profile (IPP) (I.2) - To define "good" early. * Partnership One-Pager (II.6) - For initial outreach. * Basic Partner Onboarding Checklist (Simplified II.3). * Partner Recruitment Email Sequence (II.1).

Stage 2: Emerging (Structured & Defined) * Characteristics: * Dedicated partner manager(s) or small team in place. * Formal partner program with defined tiers and benefits. * Standardized partner agreements and onboarding process. * Initial PRM or CRM usage for partner tracking. * Basic sales and product training available to partners. * Early attempts at joint marketing. * KPIs are defined but reporting might be manual. * Blueprint Focus (in addition to Stage 1): * Partner Strategy Plan (I.5) - First formal plan. * Partner Program Architecture (I.6) - Formalize tiers & benefits. * 3C/4C Partner Evaluation Framework (I.3) - For vetting. * Partner Onboarding Checklist (II.3) - Full version. * Discovery Call Script/Guide (II.4). * Partner Pitch Deck (II.5). * Partner Training Deck (III.2) - Foundational. * Internal Alignment Playbook (I.7) - Initial RoE.

Stage 3: Scaled (Proactive & Integrated) * Characteristics: * Mature partner team with specialized roles (ops, marketing, enablement). * Well-defined partner segments and differentiated GTM strategies. * Robust PRM system integrated with CRM and other tools. * Comprehensive enablement programs with certifications. * Consistent joint marketing campaigns and MDF programs. * Automated KPI tracking and reporting; regular QBRs. * Strong internal alignment and clear RoE. * Blueprint Focus (in addition to Stage 1 & 2): * All templates are relevant and should be actively used and refined. * Deeper dives into: Competitive Differentiation (I.4), ICP Alignment Tracker (II.7), Partner Enablement Roadmap (III.1). * Sophistication in Partner Strategy Plan (I.5) - OKRs, budget, cross-functional alignment. * Expansion of Internal Alignment Playbook (I.7) - Conflict resolution, incentives.

Stage 4: Optimized (Ecosystem-Led & Innovative) * Characteristics: * Partner ecosystem is a core driver of company growth and strategy. * Focus on co-innovation and developing new joint solutions. * Data-driven decision-making for all aspects of the partner program. * Strong partner community and advocacy. * Partners proactively contribute to product roadmap and strategy. * Ecosystem thinking is embedded across the organization. * Continuous improvement cycles for all partner processes. * Blueprint Focus (Continuous Refinement & Expansion): * Emphasis on strategic elements of Partner Business Case (I.1) for new ecosystem initiatives. * Highly dynamic Partner Strategy Plan (I.5) with focus on innovation and ecosystem health metrics. * Advanced partner segmentation and co-innovation frameworks. * Strong emphasis on Partner Community Engagement and Feedback Loops (I.5.8). * Measuring and optimizing the ROI of the entire ecosystem.

docs.title: How to Use This Template

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Customers increasingly require their vendors — and those vendors' partners — to demonstrate SOC 2 compliance. Use this guide to communicate requirements to partners who handle, transmit, or have access to customer data.

Steps: 1. Customize sections with your specific data environment 2. Share with Gold/Strategic partners during onboarding 3. Request partner's current SOC 2 report or equivalents 4. Review annually or upon significant partner change

docs.title: SOC 2 Compliance Guide for Partners
docs.text: Issued by: [Company Name] Security Team Version: 1.0 Review Date: [Date + 12 months] Applies to: Partners with access to [Company] systems, customer data, or production environments

docs.title: WHY THIS MATTERS
docs.text:
[Company] holds SOC 2 Type II certification. Partners who access our systems or customer data are required to demonstrate equivalent controls — or operate under our security framework.

Failure to meet these requirements may result in: - Restricted access to production environments - Delay or suspension of integration approvals - Exclusion from Gold/Strategic tier programs

docs.title: SCOPE OF THIS GUIDE
docs.text:
This guide applies when a partner:

  • Accesses [Company] production APIs with customer data in scope
  • Handles, stores, or processes [Company] customer PII or confidential data
  • Integrates with [Company] systems via shared credentials or service accounts
  • Provides professional services inside a customer's environment alongside [Company] software

Not in scope: Partners who only resell or refer — with no data access.

docs.title: SOC 2 TRUST SERVICE CRITERIA (OVERVIEW)
docs.text: Criteria Description Required for Partners? Security (CC) System protected against unauthorized access Yes — All partners Availability (A) System available per SLA commitments Yes — for SaaS integrations Processing Integrity (PI) Processing complete, valid, and accurate Where applicable Confidentiality (C) Confidential info protected as committed Yes — data-handling partners Privacy (P) PII collected, used, retained, disposed per policy Yes — PII in scope

docs.title: Level 1 — API / Integration Access (No Customer PII)
docs.text:
Control Requirement Authentication OAuth 2.0 or API key rotation every [90] days Transport security TLS 1.2+ for all API calls Credential storage No hardcoded credentials; use secrets manager Logging API access logged and retained [90] days Incident response Notify [Company Security] within [24 hours] of suspected breach

Evidence required: Self-attestation form (annual)

docs.title: Level 2 — Customer Data Access (PII or Confidential)
docs.text:
All Level 1 controls plus:

Control Requirement SOC 2 report SOC 2 Type II report (< 12 months old) or equivalent Access control Role-based access; least privilege enforced Encryption at rest AES-256 or equivalent for stored customer data MFA Required for all staff with data access Background checks Required for all staff with production access Subprocessor disclosure List all subprocessors handling [Company] data DPA signed Data Processing Addendum required

Evidence required: Current SOC 2 Type II report + DPA

docs.title: Level 3 — Managed Service / Full Production Access
docs.text:
All Level 1 + Level 2 controls plus:

Control Requirement Annual pen test By qualified third party; results shared Vulnerability management Critical vulns patched within [7] days Security training Annual security awareness training, documented Incident response plan Written IRP, tested annually Business continuity BCP tested within prior 12 months Insurance Cyber liability coverage ≥ $[amount]

Evidence required: SOC 2 Type II + pen test summary + security controls attestation

docs.title: Step 1 — Initial Submission (Onboarding)
docs.text:
Partners submit the following to [security@company.com]:

Document Level 1 Level 2 Level 3 Self-attestation form ✅ ✅ ✅ SOC 2 Type II report — ✅ ✅ Signed DPA — ✅ ✅ Pen test executive summary — — ✅ Subprocessor list — ✅ ✅

docs.title: Step 2 — Review
docs.text:
[Company] Security reviews within [15 business days]. Outcome:

  • Approved — Partner access granted / maintained
  • Conditional — Access granted with remediation plan (90-day window)
  • Denied — Material gaps; access suspended until resolved

docs.title: Step 3 — Annual Renewal
docs.text: Partners must re-submit evidence annually. Automated reminders sent [60] days before expiration.

docs.title: ACCEPTABLE ALTERNATIVES TO SOC 2
docs.text:
If a partner does not have SOC 2 Type II, [Company] may accept:

Alternative Notes ISO 27001 certification Current certificate required FedRAMP authorization If applicable to partner's product PCI DSS Level 1 For payment-data-specific controls [Company] security questionnaire Level 1 partners only; scored ≥ [80%]

docs.title: INCIDENT NOTIFICATION REQUIREMENTS
docs.text:
Partners must notify [Company] at [security@company.com] within [24 hours] of becoming aware of:

  • Unauthorized access to systems handling [Company] data
  • Confirmed or suspected breach of [Company] customer data
  • Ransomware or destructive malware affecting in-scope systems
  • Loss or theft of devices containing [Company] data

Include in notification: - Date/time discovered - Systems and data potentially affected - Actions taken so far - Point of contact for incident response coordination

docs.title: CHECKLIST — PARTNER ONBOARDING
docs.text:
• Determine access level (1, 2, or 3)
  • Collect required evidence per level
  • Review and approve / conditionally approve
  • Execute DPA (Level ⅔)
  • Document approval and expiration in partner record
  • Set renewal reminder
  • Add partner to security incident notification list

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this template to build a business case for launching, expanding, or refining a partner program or initiative.

Steps: 1. Review each section and prompt. 2. Gather relevant data (market, financial, internal alignment, etc.). 3. Fill in each section with specific, concise, and data-driven responses. 4. Reference the "Related Templates" for supporting information. 5. Review with stakeholders before finalizing.

docs.title: Core Recommendation
docs.text:
In 2–3 concise sentences, what is the specific partnership initiative being proposed, and what primary business objective does it address?

Example: "We recommend launching a co-sell program with strategic ISVs in the cybersecurity space to penetrate the enterprise FSI market and accelerate new logo acquisition."

docs.title: Strategic Rationale & Urgency
docs.text:
Why is this initiative critical for our business now? What market forces, competitive pressures, or unique opportunities necessitate this action?

Example: "This addresses a critical product gap identified by our enterprise sales team, counters Competitor X's recent market traction, and aligns with our annual strategic pillar of expanding into the FSI vertical."

docs.title: Anticipated Impact & Key Metric
docs.text:
What is the single most significant, measurable outcome expected?

Example: "$XM in partner-influenced ARR within 24 months," "Reduce customer churn by Y% through integrated solutions," "Increase market share in Z segment by X%."

docs.title: Investment Ask (Headline)

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text:
1. Do Nothing Analysis: Use this as a strategic tool, not just a formality. Highlight risks of inaction and missed opportunities.

  2. Phased Approach: Consider a pilot program if resources are constrained. Use learnings to de-risk larger rollout.

  3. Data-Driven: Support all projections and assumptions with market data and historical performance.

  4. Stakeholder Alignment: Ensure all key stakeholders are consulted and aligned before finalizing.

Purpose: Use this template to define the characteristics of ideal partners and create a scalable, objective filter for partner recruitment, prioritization, and ongoing management.

docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this framework to objectively evaluate potential partners and assess ongoing partner performance.

Steps: 1. Review each criterion and its components. 2. Gather relevant data and evidence. 3. Score each component objectively. 4. Calculate overall scores. 5. Use results to inform decisions and action plans.

docs.title: Framework Overview
docs.text:
graph TD
    subgraph Core_3C[Core Criteria - 80%]
        A[Capacity<br/>25%] --> C[3C/4C<br/>Evaluation]
        B[Capability<br/>30%] --> C
        CC[Commitment<br/>25%] --> C
    end

    subgraph Extended_4C[Extended Criteria - 20%]
        D[Cultural Fit<br/>20%] --> C
    end

    C --> E[Weighted<br/>Score]
    E --> F{Go/No-Go<br/>Threshold: 3.5}
    F -->|Pass| G[Proceed]
    F -->|Fail| H[Develop<br/>Plan]

    style Core_3C fill:#e1f5fe
    style Extended_4C fill:#f3e5f5
    style C fill:#fff3e0
    style E fill:#fff3e0
    style F fill:#ffebee
    style G fill:#e8f5e9
    style H fill:#fff3e0

docs.title: Rating Scale
docs.text:
1. Exceptional (5)
  2. Exceeds all expectations
  3. Best-in-class performance
  4. Industry leader

  5. Strategic differentiator

  6. Strong (4)

  7. Meets all expectations
  8. Consistent performance
  9. Reliable partner

  10. Growth potential

  11. Adequate (3)

  12. Meets basic requirements
  13. Room for improvement
  14. Development needed

  15. Potential risk areas

  16. Weak (2)

  17. Below expectations
  18. Significant gaps
  19. High risk areas

  20. Immediate action needed

  21. Critical (1)

  22. Major concerns
  23. Deal-breaker issues
  24. Immediate intervention required
  25. Consider termination

docs.title: Weighting System
docs.text:
• Capacity: 25%
  • Capability: 30%
  • Commitment: 25%
  • Cultural Fit: 20%

docs.title: Initial Assessment
docs.text:
1. Gather required documentation
  2. Conduct interviews
  3. Review references
  4. Analyze historical data
  5. Score each criterion

docs.title: Ongoing Review
docs.text:
1. Quarterly performance review
  2. Annual comprehensive assessment
  3. Continuous monitoring
  4. Regular feedback sessions
  5. Action plan updates

docs.title: Decision Framework
docs.text:
• Go/No-Go Threshold: Minimum 3.5 average score
  • Critical Areas: Must score at least 3.0 in each core criterion
  • Improvement Plans: Required for scores below 3.0
  • Termination Triggers: Scores below 2.0 in critical areas
flowchart LR
    subgraph Initial[Initial Assessment]
        A1[Gather Docs] --> A2[Conduct Interviews]
        A2 --> A3[Review References]
        A3 --> A4[Analyze Data]
        A4 --> A5[Score Criteria]
    end

    subgraph Ongoing[Ongoing Review]
        B1[Quarterly Review] --> B2[Annual Assessment]
        B2 --> B3[Continuous Monitoring]
        B3 --> B4[Feedback Sessions]
        B4 --> B5[Update Plans]
    end

    subgraph Decision[Decision Framework]
        C1[Calculate Score] --> C2{Avg ≥ 3.5?}
        C2 -->|Yes| C3[Go / Continue]
        C2 -->|No| C4{Core ≥ 3.0?}
        C4 -->|Yes| C5[Dev Plan]
        C4 -->|No| C6[Exit / Terminate]
    end

    A5 --> C1
    B5 --> C1

    style Initial fill:#e3f2fd
    style Ongoing fill:#e8f5e9
    style Decision fill:#fff3e0
    style C3 fill:#c8e6c9
    style C5 fill:#fff9c4
    style C6 fill:#ffcdd2
