docs.title: How to Use This Template
docs.text:
Purpose: Use this template when ending a partner relationship to ensure a professional, thorough, and legally sound termination process that protects all parties involved.

Steps: 1. Review the exit decision criteria to confirm termination is appropriate 2. Assemble the exit team and assign responsibilities 3. Work through each checklist phase systematically 4. Document all communications and actions 5. Conduct a post-exit review to capture learnings 6. Reference the "Related Templates" for supporting information

docs.title: Exit Triggers
docs.text: Trigger Category Examples Urgency Performance Consistently missing targets, declining engagement Medium Strategic Market pivot, M&A, program restructuring Low-Medium Compliance Contract breach, ethical violations High Mutual Both parties agree to end relationship Low Business Partner bankruptcy, acquisition by competitor High Customer Impact Partner harming customer relationships High

docs.title: Exit Decision Framework
docs.text:
Before proceeding, confirm:

  • Exit has been reviewed and approved by appropriate stakeholders
  • Alternative remediation options have been considered
  • Business impact assessment has been completed
  • Legal counsel has reviewed the situation
  • Communication plan has been drafted

docs.title: 1.1 Exit Team Assembly
docs.text: Role Responsibility Assigned To Exit Lead Overall coordination, timeline management [Name] Legal Contract review, compliance, documentation [Name] Finance Outstanding payments, reconciliation [Name] Sales Customer transition, pipeline handoff [Name] Partner Manager Partner communication, relationship [Name] Marketing Co-branded materials, public messaging [Name] IT/Security System access, data handling [Name] Executive Sponsor Escalation, final decisions [Name]

docs.title: 1.2 Contract & Legal Review
docs.text:
• Review partnership agreement termination clauses
  • Identify required notice period: [X days/months]
  • Document any contract breaches (if applicable)
  • Review non-compete/non-solicitation provisions
  • Identify IP and data ownership requirements
  • Review confidentiality obligations (ongoing)
  • Consult legal on potential liabilities
  • Prepare formal termination notice

Notice Period Required: [X] days from [Date] Earliest Effective End Date: [Date]

docs.title: 1.3 Financial Assessment
docs.text: Item Amount Status Action Required Outstanding Commissions $[X] [Owed/Paid] [Action] Unpaid Invoices (from partner) $[X] [Outstanding/Collected] [Action] MDF/Co-op Balance $[X] [Owed/Clawback] [Action] Deal Registration Credits $[X] [Active/Expire] [Action] Refund Obligations $[X] [Pending/Processed] [Action] Security Deposits $[X] [Return/Forfeit] [Action]

docs.title: 1.4 Customer Impact Assessment
docs.text:
Joint Customers List:

Customer Relationship Owner Active Projects Transition Plan [Customer 1] [Your Co/Partner] [Y/N] [Plan] [Customer 2] [Your Co/Partner] [Y/N] [Plan] [Customer 3] [Your Co/Partner] [Y/N] [Plan]

Pipeline Impact:

Opportunity Stage Value Transition Owner Risk Level [Opp 1] [Stage] $[X] [Name] [High/Med/Low] [Opp 2] [Stage] $[X] [Name] [High/Med/Low]

docs.title: 2.1 Communication Preparation
docs.text: Key Messages to Convey: - Clear statement that partnership is ending - Effective date of termination - Reason (as appropriate and legally advised) - Transition timeline and process - Commitment to professional wind-down - Next steps and points of contact

docs.title: 2.2 Notification Checklist
docs.text:
• Schedule call with partner leadership (do not email first)
  • Prepare talking points and FAQs
  • Have termination letter ready to send immediately after call
  • Brief internal stakeholders before notification
  • Document the conversation

Notification Call Details: | Field | Details | |-------|---------| | Date/Time | [Date/Time] | | Your Attendees | [Names] | | Partner Attendees | [Names] | | Call Duration | [Expected duration] | | Follow-up Email Sent | [ ] Yes |

docs.title: 2.3 Termination Letter Elements
docs.text:
The formal termination letter should include:

  • Date of notice
  • Reference to agreement being terminated
  • Effective termination date
  • Reason for termination (if appropriate)
  • Wind-down period expectations
  • Outstanding obligations (both parties)
  • Return of materials/data requirements
  • Confidentiality reminder
  • Contact for questions
  • Signature from authorized representative

docs.title: 3.1 System Access Revocation
docs.text: System/Access Revocation Date Owner Status Partner Portal [Date] [IT] [ ] CRM Access [Date] [IT] [ ] Demo Environments [Date] [IT] [ ] Slack/Teams Channels [Date] [IT] [ ] API Keys/Credentials [Date] [IT] [ ] Training Platforms [Date] [IT] [ ] Marketing Asset Library [Date] [Mktg] [ ] Deal Registration System [Date] [Sales] [ ] Support Ticketing [Date] [Support] [ ]

docs.title: 3.2 Marketing & Brand Wind-Down
docs.text:
• Remove partner from website partner directory
  • Request removal of your logo from partner's site
  • Recall co-branded materials
  • Remove partner from marketing automation lists
  • Cancel joint campaigns in progress
  • Remove partner testimonials/case studies
  • Update any joint press releases
  • Archive (don't delete) co-marketing assets

Co-branded Material Inventory:

Material Location Action Due Date Status [Item 1] [Where] [Remove/Archive] [Date] [ ] [Item 2] [Where] [Remove/Archive] [Date] [ ]

docs.title: 3.3 Customer Transition
docs.text:
For each affected customer:

  • Notify customer of partnership change
  • Introduce new point of contact (if applicable)
  • Transfer open support tickets
  • Transition active projects/implementations
  • Update customer records in CRM
  • Document any commitments made jointly
  • Schedule check-in post-transition

Customer Communication Template:

Dear [Customer],

We're writing to inform you of a change in our partner ecosystem. Effective [Date], [Partner Name] will no longer be a [Your Company] partner.

[If customer was brought by partner: Your relationship with [Your Company] will continue uninterrupted. Your new point of contact is [Name] at [email].]

[If customer has active project: Any ongoing work will continue seamlessly. [Transition details].]

We remain committed to your success and are here to answer any questions.

Best regards, [Your Name]

docs.title: 3.4 Data & IP Handling
docs.text:
• Identify all partner-held company data
  • Request return or certified destruction of data
  • Retrieve any company materials held by partner
  • Revoke licenses to your IP/software
  • Return any partner materials you hold
  • Document chain of custody for sensitive data
  • Obtain written confirmation of data destruction

Data Inventory:

Data Type Location Action Confirmation Customer lists [Location] [Return/Destroy] [ ] Product documentation [Location] [Return/Destroy] [ ] Pricing/proposals [Location] [Return/Destroy] [ ] Technical specs [Location] [Return/Destroy] [ ] Training materials [Location] [Revoke access] [ ]

docs.title: 3.5 Financial Close-Out
docs.text:
• Calculate final commission payments
  • Process any outstanding invoices
  • Handle MDF/co-op fund reconciliation
  • Determine refund or clawback amounts
  • Issue final payment (if owed)
  • Collect final payment (if owed to you)
  • Document all financial transactions
  • Close partner account in finance systems

docs.title: 4.1 Internal Stakeholder Notification
docs.text: Stakeholder Group Notification Method Timing Owner Status Executive Team Meeting Before external [Name] [ ] Sales Team Team meeting Day of [Name] [ ] Customer Success Team meeting Day of [Name] [ ] Support Team Email + meeting Day of [Name] [ ] Marketing Email Day of [Name] [ ] All Hands (if needed) Announcement Day 1 [Name] [ ]

docs.title: 4.2 Internal Talking Points
docs.text:
For Sales Team: - Why the partnership ended (appropriate level of detail) - How to handle customer questions - Pipeline transition process - What to say / what not to say - Who to escalate concerns to

For Customer-Facing Teams: - Approved messaging for customer inquiries - Alternative partners to recommend - Escalation path for sensitive situations

docs.title: 5.1 Verification Checklist
docs.text:
• All system access confirmed revoked
  • All co-branded materials removed
  • Customer transitions completed
  • Financial matters settled
  • Data return/destruction confirmed
  • Legal obligations documented as met
  • Internal systems updated
  • Documentation archived

docs.title: 5.2 Relationship Monitoring
docs.text: Monitoring Item Frequency Owner Notes Former partner's messaging about you Weekly (first month) [Marketing] Customer feedback on transition Ongoing [CS] Competitive activity Monthly [Sales] LinkedIn/social mentions Weekly [Marketing]

docs.title: 5.3 Post-Exit Review
docs.text:
Schedule: [Date, within 30 days of exit completion]

Review Questions: 1. Was the exit handled professionally? 2. Were customers adequately protected? 3. Did we meet all legal/contractual obligations? 4. What could we have done better? 5. Were there warning signs we missed earlier? 6. What can we learn for partner selection going forward? 7. Any process improvements needed?

Learnings & Action Items:

Learning Action Owner [Learning 1] [Improvement] [Name] [Learning 2] [Improvement] [Name]

docs.title: Template 1: Initial Notification Call Script
docs.text:
"Thank you for making time to speak with us. I want to be direct with you - we've made the difficult decision to end our partnership, effective [Date].

[If performance-related]: Despite our efforts to work through the challenges we've discussed in recent months, we haven't seen the progress we need.

[If strategic]: This is a business decision driven by changes in our strategy/market, not a reflection on your team.

We're committed to a professional transition. Our priorities are [customer protection / honoring commitments / clean wind-down].

I'll send a formal letter after this call. [Name] will be your primary contact for the transition. Do you have any immediate questions?"

docs.title: Template 2: Formal Termination Letter
docs.text:
[Date]

[Partner Contact Name]
[Partner Company]
[Address]

RE: Termination of Partnership Agreement dated [Original Date]

Dear [Name],

This letter serves as formal notice of termination of the Partnership Agreement
between [Your Company] ("Company") and [Partner Company] ("Partner") dated
[Agreement Date].

In accordance with Section [X] of the Agreement, the effective termination
date shall be [Date], which is [X] days from the date of this notice.

During the wind-down period, both parties agree to:
- [Obligation 1]
- [Obligation 2]
- [Obligation 3]

Outstanding matters to be addressed:
- [Item 1]
- [Item 2]

Please direct any questions regarding this termination to [Name] at [email].

We appreciate the collaboration over the past [duration] and wish you
continued success.

Sincerely,

[Signature]
[Name]
[Title]
[Company]

docs.title: Template 3: Customer Notification (Neutral Tone)
docs.text:
Subject: Update on Our Partner Ecosystem

Dear [Customer Name],

We're reaching out to share an update about our partner ecosystem that
may affect your account.

Effective [Date], [Partner Name] will no longer be a certified partner
of [Your Company].

What this means for you:
- [Impact statement - e.g., "Your support and service continuity is our
  top priority"]
- [Transition details - e.g., "Your new dedicated contact is..."]
- [Reassurance - e.g., "All existing commitments will be honored"]

If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach
out to [Name] at [email] or [phone].

Thank you for your continued partnership.

Best regards,
[Name]

docs.title: Common Contract Provisions to Review
docs.text: Provision What to Check Implication Termination for Convenience Notice period required Sets minimum timeline Termination for Cause Defined breach conditions May accelerate exit Survival Clauses What outlasts termination Ongoing obligations Non-Compete Duration, scope, geography Restricts future actions Non-Solicitation Employees, customers Protects relationships Confidentiality Term, scope Usually survives exit Indemnification Post-termination claims Liability exposure IP Ownership Joint work product Who owns what Data Rights Handling requirements Destruction/return

docs.title: Documentation to Retain
docs.text:
Retain the following for [X years] post-exit:

  • Original partnership agreement
  • All amendments and addenda
  • Termination notice and acknowledgment
  • Financial records and reconciliation
  • Customer transition documentation
  • Data destruction confirmations
  • Correspondence related to termination
  • Meeting notes from exit discussions

docs.title: Scenario 1: Underperforming Partner
docs.text:
Situation: Partner consistently misses targets, low engagement Approach: Graduated wind-down with warning period

  1. Document performance gaps
  2. Formal performance improvement plan (30-90 days)
  3. If no improvement, provide termination notice
  4. Standard transition timeline
  5. Offer to stay connected informally

docs.title: Scenario 2: Contract Breach
docs.text:
Situation: Partner violated agreement terms Approach: Expedited exit with legal protection

  1. Document breach with evidence
  2. Legal review and guidance
  3. Termination for cause notice (shorter notice period)
  4. Accelerated access revocation
  5. Preserve evidence for potential dispute

docs.title: Scenario 3: Mutual Agreement
docs.text:
Situation: Both parties agree partnership isn't working Approach: Collaborative wind-down

  1. Joint discussion on terms
  2. Mutually agreed timeline
  3. Positive external messaging
  4. Reference-friendly separation
  5. Leave door open for future

docs.title: Scenario 4: Partner Acquisition by Competitor
docs.text:
Situation: Partner acquired by your competitor Approach: Immediate protective action

  1. Emergency legal review
  2. Expedited access revocation
  3. Customer communication priority
  4. IP and data protection focus
  5. Competitive intelligence lockdown
